**OFFERING MEMORANDUM** **NOT FOR GENERAL DISTRIBUTION**
**IN THE UNITED STATES**

### Guala Closures S.p.A.
##### €500,000,000 3 [1]⁄4% Senior Secured Notes due 2028

Guala Closures S.p.A., a società per azioni incorporated under the laws of the Republic of Italy (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”)
€500,000,000 aggregate principal amount of its 3 [1]⁄4% Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the “Notes”). The proceeds of the Notes will be used to
redeem the Issuer’s existing floating rate senior secured notes due 2024 (the “Existing Notes”) and pay accrued interest thereon, to repay amounts
outstanding under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein) including any accrued and unpaid interest thereon, for general corporate
purposes and to pay fees and expenses associated with the Refinancing (as defined herein). The Offering is being carried out following completion of the
mandatory public tender offer for the shares of the Issuer by Special Packaging Solutions Investments S.à r.l. (“SPSI”), in which SPSI acquired the
majority of the Issuer’s outstanding shares.

The Notes will bear interest at a rate equal to 3.25% per annum. Interest will accrue from the Issue Date (as defined below). The Notes will mature
on June 15, 2028. The Issuer will pay interest on the Notes semi-annually in arrears on June 15 and December 15 of each year, beginning on
December 15, 2021. Prior to June 15, 2024, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes by paying a “make-whole”
premium. At any time on or after June 15, 2024, the Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at the prices set forth in this offering memorandum (the
“Offering Memorandum”). In addition, prior to June 15, 2024, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the Notes (including the aggregate
principal amount of any additional Notes issued) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings so long as at least 50% of the original principal
amount of the Notes (excluding any additional Notes), issued under the Indenture (as defined herein) remain outstanding. Prior to June 15, 2024, the
Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional
Notes issued) in each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof. In the event of certain developments affecting
taxation, the Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and
unpaid interest. In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the
outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu
of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem
the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes.
See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption”.

Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a “change of control”, the Issuer will be required to make an offer to purchase the outstanding
Notes at a purchase price of 101% of their principal amount. A change of control triggering event, however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a
specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with the first such event.

The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer, will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s future debt that is expressly
subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and will rank pari passu in right of payment with the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not so
subordinated, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility (as defined herein). On the Issue Date, no subsidiary of the Issuer will
be required to provide a Notes Guarantee (as defined below). Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein), the
Notes will be guaranteed (collectively, the “Notes Guarantees” and each, a “Notes Guarantee”) on a senior secured basis by certain of the Issuer’s
subsidiaries (collectively, the “Guarantors” and each a “Guarantor”) within 180 days from the Business Day falling immediately after the Issue Date.
The Notes Guarantees will rank pari passu in right of payment with all of such Guarantor’s existing and future indebtedness that is not subordinated to
such Notes Guarantee. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to contractual and legal limitations and may be released under certain circumstances. The
Guarantors will also guarantee the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility on a senior secured basis. Subject to and in accordance with the
Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will be secured by first-priority security interests over substantially the same rights, property and assets that secure
the Revolving Credit Facility as further described herein and on the timeframes described herein. See “Description of the Notes—Security”. Under the
terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility, counterparties to certain hedging obligations (if any)
and creditors of certain additional indebtedness that we may incur in the future, including certain hedging agreements, will receive proceeds from the
enforcement of the security interests in priority to holders of the Notes. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Collateral will be
subject to the limitations described in “Insolvency Considerations and Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Collateral”.

Subject to and as set forth in “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes”, the Issuer will not be liable to pay any additional amounts to holders of
the Notes in relation to any withholding or deduction required pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 239 of April 1, 1996 (as the same may be
amended or supplemented from time to time) or pursuant to Legislative Decree No. 461 of November 21, 1997 (as the same may be amended, or
supplemented from time to time) where the Notes are held by a person resident in a country that does not allow for satisfactory exchange of information
with Italy (as per the Ministerial Decree of the Minister of Economy and Finance of September 4, 1996 as amended, supplemented and replaced) and
otherwise in the circumstances as described in “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes”.

There is currently no public market for the Notes. This Offering Memorandum constitutes a prospectus for purposes of Part IV of the Luxembourg law
on prospectuses for securities dated July 16, 2019. Application has been made to list the Notes on the Official List of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange
and for trading on the Euro MTF Market of the Luxembourg Stock Exchange upon their issuance. The Euro MTF Market is not a regulated market for the
purposes of the MiFID II (Directive 2014/65/EU).

The Notes will initially be issued in the form of registered global notes. The Notes will be issued in registered form in minimum denominations of
€100,000 and in integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. The Notes will be represented on issue by one or more global notes, which will be
delivered through Euroclear Bank SA/ NV (“Euroclear”) and Clearstream Banking S.A. (“Clearstream”) on July 7, 2021 (the “Issue Date”). See
“Book-Entry, Delivery and Form”.

**Investing in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. See “Risk Factors” beginning on page 35.**

**Price for the Notes: 100% plus accrued interest, if any, from the Issue Date**

**The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been and will not be registered under the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended**
**(the “U.S. Securities Act”), or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction, and may not be offered or sold within the United States**
**except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the U.S. Securities Act. In the**
**United States, the Offering is being made only to “qualified institutional buyers” (as defined in Rule 144A of the U.S. Securities Act) in**
**compliance with Rule 144A under the U.S. Securities Act (“Rule 144A”) and outside the United States to non-U.S. persons in reliance**
**on Regulation S under the Securities Act. You are hereby notified that the initial purchasers of the Notes may be relying on the**
**exemption from the provisions of Section 5 of the U.S. Securities Act. For further details about eligible offerees and resale restrictions,**
**see “Plan of Distribution” and “Transfer Restrictions”.**

_Changes to Accounting Standards_

We made certain changes to accounting standards during the periods under review. Below we
describe changes that had significant impacts on our Financial Statements during these periods. Other
amendments did not have a significant impact in prior periods and are not expected to significantly affect
the current or future periods. See notes 2(c) “Changes in accounting standards” to each of the Financial
Statements for further information on accounting policies adopted during the relevant period.

_Application of IFRS 16_

The International Accounting Standards Board issued IFRS 16 (Leases) in January 2016. The Issuer
has applied IFRS 16 starting from January 1, 2019. IFRS 16 introduces a single lease accounting model for
lessees. A lessee recognises a right-of-use asset representing its right to use the underlying asset and a lease
liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. The accounting model for lessors has not
changed substantially from the IAS 17 model.

The Issuer has elected to apply the modified retrospective approach whereby the financial
information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 were not adjusted and no first time adoption
(“FTA”) effects were recognized in the reserves at January 1, 2019. Therefore, the comparative figures for
2018 included in the 2019 Financial Statements are prepared in accordance with IAS 17 on the same basis
with those reported in the consolidated financial statements at December 31, 2018.

Prior to application of IFRS 16, the Issuer determined whether a contract was, or contained, a lease at
the inception date in accordance with IFRIC 4 (Determining Whether an Arrangement Contains a Lease).
The Issuer now determines whether a contract is, or contains, a lease based on the new definition of
IFRS 16. Specifically, the new standard establishes that a contract is or contains a lease if the contract
conveys the right to control the use of an identified asset for a period of time in exchange for
consideration.

The Group has recognized new assets and liabilities for its operating leases (as per the definition of
IAS 17) of land, warehouse and factory facilities, production lines, vehicles used within the facilities and IT
hardware. Following the application of IFRS 16, the nature of expenses related to those leases has changed
because the Group recognizes a depreciation charge for right-of-use assets and interest expense on lease
liabilities and no longer accounts for lease payments. Previously, the Group recognized operating lease
expense on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease, and recognized assets and liabilities only to the
extent that there was a timing difference between actual lease payments and the expense recognized.
Short-term leases (i.e., with a term of less than 12 months) and leases for which the underlying asset is of
low value, which have been excluded from the scope of IFRS 16 as per the practical expedient, are
recognized as operating expense on a straight-line basis over the lease term.

For further information on the application of IFRS 16 and its impact on our financial information, see
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting
_the Comparability of Operations” and note 2(c) to the 2019 Financial Statements included elsewhere in this_
Offering Memorandum.

_Recent Accounting Pronouncements_

A number of new standards are effective for annual periods beginning after April 1, 2021. The Issuer
has not early adopted the new or amended standards given the expectation that they will not have a
significant impact on the annual financial statements. For further Recent Accounting Pronouncements,
please see note 3 of the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements.

based on the markets where our customers’ end-products are sold.

**Other Financial Measures**

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain non-IFRS measures, including EBIT, EBITDA,
Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin.

   - We define EBIT as profit (loss) before taxation and financial income and expenses.

   - We define EBITDA as profit (loss) before taxation, financial income and expenses and
depreciation and amortization.

   - We define Adjusted EBIT as EBIT as adjusted to remove the effects of certain non-recurring and
non-core income and charges.

  - We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA, as adjusted to remove the effects of certain
non-recurring and non-core income and charges.

  - We define EBIT margin as EBIT divided by net revenue and expressed as a percentage.

  - We define Adjusted EBITDA margin as Adjusted EBITDA divided by net revenue and expressed
as a percentage.

We believe that EBIT and EBITDA are useful indicators of our ability to incur and service our
indebtedness and can assist certain investors, security analysts and other interested parties in evaluating us.
We believe that Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted EBITDA are relevant measures for assessing our
performance because they are adjusted for certain items which, we believe, are not indicative of our
underlying operating performance and thus aid in an understanding of our Profit and EBIT.

EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBITDA and similar measures are used by different
companies for differing purposes and are often calculated in ways that reflect the circumstances of those
companies. You should exercise caution in comparing EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted
EBITDA as reported by us to EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted EBITDA of other
companies. EBITDA as presented here differs from the definition of “Consolidated EBITDA” contained
in the Indenture as described under the caption “Description of the Notes”, or for the purposes of any of
our other indebtedness. The information presented by both EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted
EBITDA is unaudited and has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS or any other accounting
standards. In addition, the presentation of these measures is not intended to and does not comply with the
reporting requirements of the SEC. Compliance with the SEC’s requirements would require us to make
changes to the presentation of this information.

None of EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT nor Adjusted EBITDA is a measurement of performance
under IFRS and you should not consider EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT or Adjusted EBITDA as an
alternative to net income determined in accordance with IFRS, as the case may be, or to cash flows from
operations, investing activities or financing activities. EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted
EBITDA have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation. Some of these
limitations are:

   - the do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or
contractual commitments;

   - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

   - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service
interest or principal payments on our debt;

xiv


-----

   - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets depreciated and amortized
will often need to be replaced in the future and EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA do not reflect any
cash requirements that would be required for such replacements;

  - some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA
reflect cash payments that were made, or will in the future be made; and

  - the fact that other companies in our industry may calculate EBIT, EBITDA, Adjusted EBIT and
Adjusted EBITDA differently than we do, which limits their usefulness as comparative measures.

We also present Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates
Safety Closures, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Luxury Closures, Net Revenue at Constant
Exchange Rates Roll-on Closures, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Roll-on for Wine Closures,
Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Other Revenue, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates
Europe, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Americas, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates
Asia, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Oceania, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates
Africa, EBIT at Constant Exchange Rates, EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates, Adjusted EBITDA at
Constant Exchange Rates, Adjusted EBIT at Constant Exchange Rates and Net Revenue at Constant
Exchange Rates Spirits Market for certain periods, which were prepared by translating the results of a
given period in each currency other than the euro, our reporting currency, applying the average exchange
rate of such currency in the previous comparative period instead of applying the period-end exchange rate
as we do when preparing our consolidated results. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates, Net
Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Safety Closures, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Luxury
Closures, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Roll-on Closures, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange
Rates Roll-on for Wine Closures, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Other Revenue, Net Revenue
at Constant Exchange Rates Europe, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Americas, Net Revenue at
Constant Exchange Rates Asia, Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Oceania, Net Revenue at
Constant Exchange Rates Africa, EBIT at Constant Exchange Rates, EBITDA at Constant Exchange
Rates, Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates, Adjusted EBIT at Constant Exchange Rates, Net
Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates Spirits Market do not represent the amount of cash received by the
Group and are not recognized measures under IFRS. Although the Group does not believe that these
measures are a substitute for IFRS measures in light of the significant translation effects of movements in
exchange rates due to the international nature of the Group’s business, the Group believes that computing
Net revenue, EBIT, EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA results for any given period at constant exchange
rates is the most appropriate means to compare the Group’s current results of operations against the
previous year. The non-IFRS measures may not be comparable to similarly titled measures of other
companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute
for an analysis of the Group’s operating results as reported under IFRS.

We also present the non-IFRS measures of Net Working Capital, Net Capital Expenditure, Growth
Capital Expenditure, Maintenance Capital Expenditure, EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure,
Adjusted cash conversion ratio, Net Senior Secured Debt and Net Financial Debt.

   - We define Net Working Capital as inventories plus trade receivables less trade payables.

   - We define Net Capital Expenditure as Acquisitions of property, plant and equipment and
intangible assets less Proceeds from sale of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets;

   - We define Growth Capital Expenditure as Net Capital Expenditure related to discretionary
investments to expand our geographical footprint or increase our manufacturing capacity and
capabilities and cost savings and efficiency projects to optimize our operations, equipment and
footprint. Growth Capital Expenditure also includes certain discretionary investments in the design,
development and production of solutions with embedded NFC technologies;

   - We define Maintenance Capital Expenditure as Net Capital Expenditure related to critical ordinary
course investments in tangible and fixed assets to ensure the continuing operation of our asset base;

   - We define EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure as Net Capital Expenditure related to
applicable EHS laws and regulations and sustainability;

   - We define Senior Secured Debt as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing as the aggregate
principal amount of the Notes excluding any amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit
Facility, and Net Senior Secured Debt as Senior Secured Debt as adjusted to give effect to the
Refinancing less cash and cash equivalents; and

xv


-----

   - We define Total Financial Debt as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing as the aggregate
principal amount of the Notes, leases under IFRS 16 and other indebtedness under certain bank
facilities (see “Capitalization”), excluding financial liabilities related to the Market Warrants and
the put options in respect of the non-controlling interests in our subsidiaries in Ukraine, Poland,
Bulgaria and Belarus. Total Financial Debt excludes any amounts outstanding under the Revolving
Credit Facility. We define Net Financial Debt as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing as Total
Financial Debt as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing less cash and cash equivalents as
adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing.

We use Net Working Capital, Net Capital Expenditure, Growth Capital Expenditure, Maintenance
Capital Expenditure, EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure and Adjusted Cash Conversion Ratio to
monitor cash flow generation. Net Working Capital, Net Capital Expenditure, Growth Capital
Expenditure, Maintenance Capital Expenditure, EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure, Adjusted
cash conversion ratio, Net Senior Secured Debt and Net Financial Debt are not measures of liquidity
under IFRS or U.S. GAAP and have limitations as an analytical tool, some of which include:

   - They do not deduct cash flows used in other financing activities; and

   - They do not deduct certain other items settled in cash.

Net Working Capital, Net Capital Expenditure, Growth Capital Expenditure, Maintenance Capital
Expenditure, EHS and Sustainability Capital Expenditure, Adjusted Cash Conversion Ratio, Net Senior
Secured Debt and Net Financial Debt should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available
to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our
obligations. Other companies in the industries in which we operate may calculate Net Working Capital,
Net Capital Expenditure, Growth Capital Expenditure, Maintenance Capital Expenditure, EHS and
Sustainability Capital Expenditure, Adjusted Cash Conversion Ratio, Net Senior Secured Debt and Net
Financial Debt, or other similarly titled measures differently than us, limiting their usefulness as a
comparative measure.

December 31, 2020, and subtracting the results of operations for the three months ended March 31, 2020.
The financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021 is not necessarily indicative of the
results that may be expected for the year ending December 31, 2021, and should not be used as the basis
for or prediction of an annualized calculation. Such financial information has not been audited, is not
required by or presented in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles
and has been prepared for illustrative purposes only. We believe that the financial information for the
twelve months ended March 31, 2021 is a useful indicator of our ability to develop our business and
operating cash flow and to serve our indebtedness. We present this information as it is the basis for certain

useful as supplemental measures for investors in assessing the impact of the Refinancing and our ability to
incur and service our debt, including the Notes.

**Overview**

We believe that we are the world’s leading producer of high value added closures for the spirits and
wine industry. Through ongoing development and technological innovation, we believe that we are the top
producer of non-refillable safety closures for the spirits industry with a market share by volume of units
sold worldwide of more than 60%, the leading global producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures
with a market share by volume of units sold of approximately 30%, and Europe’s largest producer of
roll-on aluminum closures for wine, spirits and olive oil, in each case, in 2019. In aggregate, as of March 31,
2021, we operated from 30 production facilities, five research and development centers and three sales
centers across 25 countries in five continents, and we produced and sold approximately 17 billion closures
across than 300 models and in more than 100 countries in 2020.

Our product lines include: Safety closures, Luxury closures, Roll-on closures and Roll-on for wine
closures. We serve customers in several geographies and across four key end-markets: Spirits, Wine, Water
and Beverages, and Oil and Condiments.

We believe that our global footprint and technologically advanced facilities, blue-chip customer base,
technology and innovation and effective cost control provide us with a competitive advantage over other
closures producers and make it more challenging for new market entrants to effectively compete in the
markets in which we sell our products. Our position is further consolidated by our extensive intellectual
property (“IP”) portfolio, with, as of March 31, 2021, over 170 active patents and other IP rights related to
the design and manufacture of closures, and continuous product innovation (over 35 new products have
been launched over the last three years).

We are the leading producer of safety closures by volume of units sold in a number of countries,
including Colombia, India, United Mexican States (“Mexico”) and Ukraine. Notably, safety, closures are
primarily used in emerging markets where there is a high risk of counterfeiting of alcohol. In addition, we
are the leading manufacturer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures in Argentina, Australia, New
Zealand, Poland (from where we serve the European market) and South Africa.

We have a wide customer portfolio, which includes blue-chip major international and regional brands
with whom we have built long-term relationships lasting more than 30 years in certain cases. We supply the
top 10 premium spirits brands worldwide, including McDowell’s, Johnnie Walker, Bacardi, Jack Daniel’s
and Absolut. The breadth and diversity of our customer base results in no single brand accounting for
more than 3% of our net revenue during the last three years.


1


-----

Over the past decade, we have developed a strong focus on sustainability and ESG issues and strived
to reduce the impact of our products and operations on the environment and climate change. We have
made a long-term commitment to the design of sustainable solutions and continuously focus, together with
selected partners, on the study, prototyping and development of closures made of materials with a low
environmental impact over their life cycle, including recycled aluminum and recycled polymers as well as
biopolymers and composite polymers. In 2020, recycled materials represented 27% of the raw materials
used in our products. In November 2020, we launched a new range of sustainable products under the
umbrella brand Blossom[™] and in December 2020, we signed an exclusivity agreement with Oceanworks[®],
the largest global marketplace for sustainable materials, in order to develop a line of T-bar closures
manufactured using fully recycled ocean-diverted plastic. We are committed to reducing the impact of our
operations and wider value chain on the environment by reducing waste, increasing energy and water
savings and using renewable energy, which is well-aligned with our focus on staying at the forefront of
product innovation. We estimate that in 2020 we reduced our Scope 1 & 2 Greenhouse Gas Emissions per
ton of finished products by approximately 8% compared to 2016. With plants and offices in 25 countries
and customers from over 100 countries, we also place great importance on diversity and inclusion as well as
talent recruitment and management. As of March 31, 2021, the percentage of women holding leadership
positions was 20.0% compared to 15.9% in 2018. In addition, following the appointment of the new board
of directors on April 30, 2021, 44% of the members of our board of directors are women.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, we generated net revenue of €564.4 million, loss of
€0.2 million, EBIT of €31.5 million, and Adjusted EBITDA of €98.2 million, resulting in an Adjusted
EBITDA margin of 17.4%. We believe that our high margins are supported by our raw material cost
management and our ability to manage raw material price fluctuations, global diversity and exposure to
growth markets and ongoing management initiatives to improve production efficiencies.

**Our product lines**

We primarily focus on producing a wide variety of specialty and other closures. Our product portfolio
ranges from the simplest screwcaps to the more complex solutions equipped with components made of
different materials with particular aesthetic or safety features.

Our Closures division represents our core business, which is specialized in the following product lines:
Safety closures, Luxury closures, Roll-on closures and Roll-on for wine closures. Safety and Luxury
closures feature a higher degree of manufacturing complexity and customization and typically generate
higher margins compared to other closures. Due to their bespoke aesthetic design specific to clients’
brands, Safety and Luxury closures are important components of the marketing strategies of premium
spirits producers and further contribute to their brand awareness and recognition.

**Product lines** **End markets**

Safety Luxury Spirits Olive oil & condiments

**_Safety closures_**

We believe that we are the world’s leading producer of safety closures for spirits, with a market share
by volume of units sold worldwide in 2019 of more than 60%. Safety closures are fitted with special devices
to limit counterfeiting of the end product and to increase safety by making them tamper-evident,
non-refillable and leak-proof. Safety closures are primarily used by our customers when selling their
products in emerging markets, where the risk of counterfeiting is highest and the product’s complexity

|Product lines|Col2|Col3|End markets|Col5|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|Safety|Luxury||Spirits|Olive oil & condiments|


2


-----

decreases the risk of imitation by competitors. Safety closures generally comprise two to 12 different
components that are primarily made out of plastic (with some aluminum mix). Our current product
portfolio comprises over 30 models, all of which can be customized to meet our customer’s requirements
and expectations.

Safety closures are equipped with technologies including tamper-evident systems that enable the
customer to understand if the bottle has been opened, non-refillable systems with internal valves of varying
complexity that prevent bottles to be re-filled, and highly technical structure configurations which make
the separation of safety non-refillable systems from the bottle neck more difficult. Our Safety closures
offering is completed with highly sophisticated smart packaging systems, such as our closures with nearfield communication (“NFC”) technology that use special microchips that are readable by all compatible
smartphones to provide consumers with the certification of product authenticity and other product data.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, our Safety closures product line generated net revenue
of €202.2 million, representing 35.8% of our net revenue for the period.

**_Luxury closures_**

Our luxury closures give a distinctive character to our customers’ brands and to improve the aesthetic
appeal of their end-products. We estimate that in the year ended December 31, 2019, we had a global
market share by volume of units of Luxury closures sold of between 6% and 8%.

Our Luxury closures line includes closures made of aluminum, plastic and wood, which are typically
designed to improve the aesthetical appeal and meet the branding needs of high-end spirits that are
produced in small quantities. Luxury closures can be designed to suit different brand and market
requirements, including screw-on, push-on and non-refillable versions with the most advanced decoration
techniques including 3D embossing and metal sputtering.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, our Luxury closures product line generated net revenue
of €29.3 million, representing 5.2% of our net revenue for the period.

**_Roll-on closures_**

We produce roll-on closures, mainly using aluminum, for spirits, mineral water, vegetable oil and
condiments sectors. We believe that we are the largest producer of standard aluminum Roll-on closures in
Poland, Ukraine and Mexico and the second largest in Russia, the United Kingdom and the United States.
Overall, we estimate that in the year ended December 31, 2019, we had a market share by volume of units
of Roll-on closures for spirits sold of approximately 15%.

Roll-on closures are primarily made out of aluminum and typically comprise up to four different
components. Our Roll-on closures portfolio ranges from the simplest screwcaps to more customized
solutions decorated with advanced techniques.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, our Roll-on product line generated net revenue of
€196.4 million, representing 34.8% of our net revenue for the period.

**_Roll-on for wine closures_**

We produce aluminum screwcap closures specifically dedicated to the wine sector that are easy to
open and convenient to store, and have a lower cost than traditional cork closures. We believe that we are
the leading producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures for the wine industry, with a market share
by volume of units sold in 2019 of approximately 30%. The market for aluminum screwcaps for wine
closures continues to grow strongly as a result of the superior performance of aluminum closures
compared to traditional cork closures and as of today screwcaps are embedded in approximately 23% of
the total bottled wines worldwide. We developed one of the widest range of screwcaps for the wine market,
incorporating several specific technical features such as controlled Oxygen Transmission Rate (“OTR”)
liners and decoration techniques such as silk screening, hot-foiling, off-setting, lithography and embossing.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, our Roll-on for wine closures product line generated
net revenue of €117.1 million, representing 20.8% of our net revenue for the period.

**Competitive strengths**

We believe we have the following competitive strengths:

**_Market leader in safety closures for spirits and roll-on for wine closures_**

According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, in 2019, the global
spirits closures market reached approximately 51 billion of units sold, of which approximately 18 billion
units in our key focus regions of India, Russia, the United States, the United Kingdom, Poland, Ukraine
and Mexico, and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2.0% between
2021 and 2024, primarily driven by growth in the safety and luxury closures markets, especially in the
United States and India. According to the same study, Guala’s global addressable Roll-on and Safety
closures markets reached approximately 37 billion units in 2019 (compared to 33 billion in 2016). In
addition, the global market for Roll-on for wine closures reached approximately 32 billion units in 2019


4


-----

(compared to 30 billion units in 2016) and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of
approximately 2.0% between 2021 and 2024. We believe we are the market leader in the production of
Safety closures for spirits with a market share by volume of units sold worldwide of more than 60%, and
the leading producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures for the wine industry with a market share by
volume of units sold of approximately 30%, in each case in 2019. We estimate that in 2019, our market
shares for Safety and Roll-on for wine closures was six and four times greater than that of our nearest
competitor, respectively. We also believe that we are a leading producer of aluminum closures for spirits in
Europe. We believe that our leadership positions are sustainable due to our commitment to quality,
research and development efforts, proprietary production technologies, long-standing customer
relationships, excellent customer service and brand recognition.

We are a renowned as a key partner in the spirits markets and sell our safety closures to some of the
most prestigious multinational producers of spirits as well as a number of important regional producers in
many of the countries in which we operate. For a spirits producer, packaging and brand are key elements
in product identification and differentiation. Through technological innovation, we offer closures that
enable our customers to better differentiate and position their brands against their competitors. We
believe that the market for safety closures for spirits, including in emerging markets where premium
brands are penetrating further, will continue to grow. See “Industry Overview”. Our safety closures help
global manufacturers of spirits to protect against counterfeiting, particularly in emerging markets where
the risk of counterfeiting is higher. As a result, we believe that we are the leading manufacturer of safety
closures in various emerging countries, including Colombia, India, Mexico and Ukraine. Both global and
local manufacturers of spirits also use safety and luxury closures to differentiate their brands.

Our aluminum screwcaps for wine closures are designed to facilitate opening and closing the bottle
and feature liners that keep the oxygenation of the wine in check so the wine retains its quality and flavour
longer. In this market, we serve some of the major wine producers as well as a number of important
regional players, such as Casella in New Zealand, Distell in South Africa and The Wine Group in the
United States. We expect that the market for aluminum screwcaps for wine closures will continue to grow
due to the advantages of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures over traditional cork closures. We believe
that we are well placed to benefit from this growth because of our ability to cross-sell to manufacturers
who also sell spirits, our capacity for decoration and design, the economies of scale permitted by our
extensive distribution network and the proximity of several of our plants to “New World” wine producers
in Australia, New Zealand, South America and South Africa.

As the only safety closures producer with a global production network, we operated 30 production
facilities and five research and development centers and three sales offices in 25 countries across five
continents as of March 31, 2021.

The strength and global reach of our platform is supported by our decentralized sales structure with a
wide network of local area managers, which enables us to be in close proximity to our key customers
worldwide, allowing us to establish and foster close relationships with industry players across geographies.
We believe our proximity to our customers enhances our ability to respond quickly to changing local
trends. In addition, our global scale enables us to source capacity from different locations based on supply
and demand levels so that we can serve our customers across multiple geographies depending on their
needs and requirements. As a result, we are able to develop new products and value added solutions that
meet the requirements of customers in our key end-markets while limiting our labor costs and creating
production synergies, all of which positions us well for future growth.

Our global platform of technologically advanced facilities is equipped with state-of-the-art
technologies, processing solutions, quality controls and machinery. Over the years, we have developed
proprietary production technologies that are crucial for the manufacture of technologically advanced
closures. As part of our efforts to make our manufacturing process more efficient by leveraging on
technological innovations, we regularly pilot and implement various projects across our manufacturing
facilities, including a multi-injection project in our facility in Colombia to develop closures made of
different plastics in the same mould in order to eliminate the assembly stage of our production process and
provide significant additional anti-counterfeiting protection to our closures. In addition, we focus on widescale flexible automation of our productions processes, which we plan to implement also for small and
medium-sized product batches. As customers increasingly demand more product customization, we believe
that our technologically advanced facilities position us to adapt to this market trend and meet the
increasingly complex specifications of our customers.

**_Long-standing and trusted blue chip customer relationships, high switching costs and diverse customer base_**

Our consistent product quality and customer service have allowed us to develop strong and longstanding relationships with our customers, both in mature and emerging markets. We enhance customer
loyalty through our research and development activities, which are often driven by the specific business
requirements of our customers. We have strong and long-standing relationships with most of the large
global producers of spirits, including Bacardi, Brown Forman, Campari, Diageo and Pernod Ricard, and
we work closely with individual brands owned by these producers. We also serve major wine producers,
such as Accolade, Castel, Caviro and Torres, Concha y Toro, Constellations Brands, Pernod Ricard and
Treasury wines. In addition, we serve a broad range of regional and local producers of spirits and wines
across all of our geographies. In 2020, approximately 30% and 70% of our net revenues was generated
from sales of products to global and regional spirits producers, respectively. We have long-term
relationships with many of our customers, which in some cases exceed 30 years.

Due to the nature of bottle closures, we work in close partnership with leading spirits and wines
producers in the study, prototyping and development of highly innovative closures specifically designed for
their end-products, particularly safety and luxury closures, which often become integral parts of the overall
packaging design featured in their advertising campaigns. For example, we have developed the “Neptune”
closure for the SKYY Vodka brand, the “Florence” closure for Pernod Ricard’s Ballantine’s in both open
pourer and non-refillable versions and the luxury quality “Ultis” closure for Pernod Ricard’s Chivas
Whiskey. In recent years, the trend for customized solutions has resulted in the increase of the share of
products that we co-design and co-develop with our customers, particularly for luxury closures. For
example, we currently co-develop all of the luxury closures with premium spirit brands including, among
others, Macallan, William Grant’s, Haig Club, Dewar’s. The trend for customized solutions has also driven
the co-development of highly customized Safety closures with brands such as Jose Cuervo, Khortitsa and
Russian Standard. At the same time, we continue to develop products that can be sold to all customers in
specific end-markets, particularly in the wine and water closures market.

The high degree integration of our closures with customers’ end-products and the fact that our
closures are covered by patents or other forms of intellectual property protection, makes it more difficult
and costly for our customers to source alternative closures from our competitors. In addition, our longstanding, collaborative relationships with leading brands and our ability to leverage our global platform to
serve their needs across multiple geographies have allowed our closures to be used in our customers’
products globally, often becoming industry standard. In safety closures, we are typically the sole supplier
for a particular brand in a particular region. At the same time, our customer base is largely diversified and,

while certain of our customers own multiple brands, no single brand accounted for more than 3% of our
net revenue in 2019 and 2020.

As a result of the time and resources invested in joint product development activities with customers,
we also often receive recognition. For example, the e-closures equipped with NeˇSTGATE[™] NFC
technology that we launched in 2020 with Vigneti Massa, a well-established winemaker located in
Piedmont, Italy, received three prestigious awards in 2019: the Alufoil Trophy, the SIMEI Innovation
Challenge and the WorldStar Award. In addition, in February 2020 we received, together with Vigneti
Massa, a special prize for innovation in the wine sector at the inaugural Food & Wine Italia Awards.

We believe that the multinational scope of our operations and our ability to meet our customers’
quality standards across geographic markets are increasingly important factors to our large global
customers. In addition, our international presence allows us to operate in close physical proximity to our
customers’ production facilities and meet their product and design requirements with greater flexibility
and at a more competitive price and quality than our competitors.

**_Highly differentiated proprietary engineered product portfolio supported by a strong focus on research and_**
**_development_**

We believe that a key reason for our strong positioning in the global markets is the wide range of
products in our portfolio, which we sell to customers operating in four key end-markets: spirits, wine, water
and beverages, and olive oil and condiments. Our safety closures, which are highly engineered packaging
components generally consist of two to 12 different components, range from tamper-evident seals to more
sophisticated non-refillable devices covering the medium to high value added range of the closures market.
Our luxury closures, typically designed for high-end spirits produced in limited quantities, are made of
both aluminum and plastic, are customized according to the requirements of our customers and can
include ribbons, seals and unusual shapes. Our roll-on closures and other product lines provide a range of
products for spirits and mineral water and often provides an entry point for up-selling customers to other
higher value added product lines. Our roll-on for wine closures are made from aluminum and customers
can choose whether or not to include a tamper-evident band for protection against counterfeiting.

In line with our long-term commitment to design sustainable solutions and increasing customer focus
on sustainability in their own products, we recently developed and launched several sustainable solutions,
such as products of our Blossom[™] line, including Greencap[®], a fully removable and disposable aluminum
screwcap made of recycled materials, a luxury T-bar closure fully made of recycled ocean-diverted plastic
and agglomerated cork that we developed in collaboration with Oceanworks[®], the largest global
marketplace for sustainable materials, and Spring Blossom, a new aluminum closure for water with a
tamper-evident ring produced from completely bio-based polymers.

Our research and development capabilities and our customer service functions enable us to
continuously improve and expand our product offering, including in response to customer feedback, and
the solutions we develop are often proprietary in nature and covered by patents, trade secrets and
know-how, all of which ensures our product portfolio remains differentiated.

**_Focus on innovation, technology and product development_**

We are committed to product research and development and the digitalization of packaging, and we
believe that we are a leading innovator in the closures industry, with a record of developing new and
enhanced products with improved functionality, reliability and sustainability. In addition, the increased
interconnectivity of our closures leads to closer integration between packaging suppliers and customers
during the designing, ordering and delivering phases as closures are closely tailored to customers’ needs.
We focus on the study, prototyping and development of highly engineered innovative solutions together
with selected partners, particularly for safety closures, and we protect our know-how by applying for
patents and other intellectual property protections for our products and processes. As of March 31, 2021,
we held, or had lodged applications for, more than 170 patents, including 113 active patent families,
10 utility model families, 5 combined patents and utility model families and 44 protected industrial designs.
Patents covered approximately 29% of our net revenue in the year ended December 31, 2020. The
proprietary nature of our products makes it more challenging for new market entrants to effectively
compete with us, as our research and development capabilities allow us to strengthen our relationships
with customers.


7


-----

We operate five research and development centers in Italy, Scotland, Mexico, Ukraine and
Luxembourg. We believe that our developments allow us to derive a significant competitive advantage in
our markets because more advanced products generally provide us with higher margins. During the last
three years, we have launched over 35 new products. Examples of some of our most recent innovations
include various e-closures with fully integrated NFC capabilities, including our new series of e-closures
under the NeˇSTGATE[™] brand, which we started to develop in 2018, including the first wine bottles
equipped with NFC technology in Europe, which we launched in partnership with Vigneti Massa in 2020,
and e-closures specifically designed for Irish whiskey Jameson, which we launched in 2020. The NFC
technology is revolutionizing conventional bottle packaging by integrating connectivity features into bottle
closures for spirits, wine, olive oil and beverages. In particular, our NeˇSTGATE[™] e-closures are equipped
with a special microchip inside the capsule that is readable by all compatible smartphones, without
downloading any specific application, providing consumers with the certification of authenticity and
unlocking all information about the product, directly linking them to the brand and boosting customer
engagement and loyalty. Our NeˇSTGATE[™] product range also comprises various QR code-based as well
as more basic serial number-based models for wine and beverages. Most recently, we designed an
electronic tamper-evident closure equipped with proximity sensors capable of detecting nearby objects in
partnership with NXP Semiconductors, which we plan to launch in the coming months. Following our
recent acquisition of a minority stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services
agency based in London, we are able to offer our customers turnkey solutions, including digital platforms,
integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions.

We also have developed proprietary manufacturing processes that help reduce our operating costs
and improve our profitability. In certain cases, we work with our customers to develop new and more
competitive products. By offering support and by providing the technical expertise and service needed to
develop new products, we have enhanced our relationships with our customers. In addition, in order to
refresh our current product portfolio and meet the increasing demand for customized products, our
research and development team is currently developing a new series of products tailored for individual
brands and equipped with innovative technological and sustainable features and with a sophisticated
design, which we expect to launch between 2021 and 2023.

**_Proven track record of successful acquisitions focused on creating long-term value_**

Over the past two decades, our growth has been complemented through strategically identified
acquisitions and other business combinations and investments, which enabled us to strengthen our market
position and further increase our market share. In doing so, we have increased the number of geographical
markets in which we operate, including Australia, Bulgaria, France, Poland, South Africa, Ukraine,
Belarus, Germany and Turkey and have expanded our presence in new segments and the types of products
which we offer, including aluminum screwcaps for wine closures. Most recently, in 2018, we acquired
United Closures and Plastics (now called Guala Closures UCP), a Scottish company with a long-standing
presence in the Scottish market, which supplies some landmark scotch whisky brands. In 2020, we acquired
Closurelogic GmbH, a German manufacturer specializing in aluminum closures mainly intended for the
glass-bottle beverage and mineral water sector, as well as its Turkish subsidiary. In the same year, we
acquired a minority stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services agency based in
London focusing on integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions, which we
increased from 20% to 30% in the first quarter of 2021. We believe that we have been successful at
identifying and integrating acquired companies within the Group and at delivering synergies. Our success
in identifying and integrating acquired companies has contributed to the diversification of our geographic
and product category profile and the maintenance of attractive margins.

**_Best-in-class financial profile with proven resilience, with a decade of strong Adjusted EBITDA margins despite_**
**_foreign exchange rate and raw materials price fluctuations_**

We manage our business with a focus on achieving and maintaining a strong Adjusted EBITDA
margin as compared to those of our industry peers. We have a strong track-record of more than a decade
of revenue growth and stability of Adjusted EBITDA margins within a very narrow and consistent range.
We believe our business is resilient against the impact of adverse foreign exchange movements and raw
materials price fluctuations. Furthermore, we believe that the diversified nature of our end-markets and
customer base, coupled with our global presence have allowed us to maintain strong performance in 2020


8


-----

despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, our Adjusted EBITDA margins are supported
by hedging arrangements covering a portion of our costs for raw materials via forward contracts. From
time to time, our Adjusted EBITDA margins are impacted by the initial dilutive effect of strategic
acquisitions; however, we strive to support our acquired businesses in order to maintain high group-wide
margins as we strive to achieve industry leading profitability. As a result, we believe our average Adjusted
EBITDA margin from 2015 to 2020 (including pre-merger Guala) was one of the three highest among our
direct competitors within the industry.

Our profit/(loss) for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, for the twelve months ended
March 31, 2021, represented 2.4%, (1.0)% and (0.0%), respectively, of our net revenue. We have achieved
strong Adjusted EBITDA margins of 18.7%, 17.1% and 17.4% in the years ended December 31, 2019 and
2020, and in the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, respectively. We were able to achieve these results
leveraging both organic and inorganic growth, in spite of the fluctuations in exchange rates and raw
material prices and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Following the economic recovery starting in
the third and fourth quarter of 2020, our sales volumes returned to pre-pandemic levels. As a result, while
our net revenue in 2020 decreased by €34.5 million, or 5.7%, to €572.0 million from €606.5 million in 2019,
our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in 2020 decreased by only €2.7 million, or 0.4%, to
€603.8 million from €606.5 million in 2019. In the first quarter of 2021, our overall sales volumes continued
to improve despite the loss of volumes from sales in the European water and beverage market, which was
negatively impacted by the restrictions implemented in the hotel, restaurant and catering (“HORECA”)
industries due to the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, while net revenue decreased by €7.6 million, or
5.2%, from €145.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €138.3 million for the three
months ended March 31, 2021, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the first quarter of 2021
increased by €1.3 million, or 0.9%, from €145.9 million in the first quarter of 2020 to €147.2 million. Our
resilient industry leading margins coupled disciplined approach to working capital and capital expenditure
led to a strong Adjusted cash conversion ratio of 88% in each of the years ended December 31, 2019 and
2020. The above information should be read in conjunction with the information contained in
“Presentation of Financial and Other Information”, and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations”._

**_Strong focus on ESG and sustainability by pursuing ambitious targets_**

Over the past decade, we have developed a strong focus on sustainability and ESG issues and
strived to reduce the impact of our products and operations on the environment and climate change.
Going forward, we intend to continue to focus on sustainability and ESG and have developed a
comprehensive strategy to optimize sustainability across our operations and identified a series of
sustainability targets. We have made a long-term commitment to the design of sustainable solutions and
have been, together with selected partners, studying, prototyping and developing closures made of
materials with a low environmental impact over their life cycle, including recycled aluminum and
recycled polymers as well as biopolymers and composite polymers. In 2020, recycled materials
represented 27% of the raw materials used in our products and we intend to increase this percentage to
35% by the end of 2025. Our product portfolio already comprises several sustainable products under the
umbrella brand Blossom[™], including Greencap[®], a fully removable and disposable aluminum screwcap
made of recycled materials, a luxury T-bar closure fully made of recycled ocean-diverted plastic and
Spring Blossom, a new aluminum closure for water with a tamper-evident ring produced from
completely bio-based polymers. In line with our long-term commitment on sustainability, we intend to
increase the share of environmentally-friendly solutions in our portfolio, by extending our existing range
of sustainable closures and developing new solutions.

In order to protect the environment, meet sustainability needs and contribute to the mitigation of the
effects of climate change, we focus on minimizing environmental pollution, reducing waste, increasing
energy and water savings and using renewable energy. We estimate that in 2020 we reduced our Scope
1 & 2 Greenhouse Gas Emissions per ton of finished products by approximately 8% compared to 2016,
and we intend to decrease such emissions further by optimizing processes and optimizing loads and
logistics across our supply chain. In addition, in the first quarter of 2021, we implemented “Iris”, a new
software developed entirely in-house, at our Spinetta Marengo facility in Italy, which is able to connect
150 pieces of machinery simultaneously, perform data analysis and make recommendations to the facility’s
operator in line with our key sustainability principles. Going forward, we plan to implement Iris at all our
facilities worldwide.


9


-----

**_Experienced and committed management team supported by clear and simple reporting lines and a decentralized_**
**_sales structure_**

We benefit from the experience of our key management who each have decades of experience in the
closures and packaging industry. In addition, in 2021 we welcomed our new Chief Executive Officer,
Mr. Gabriele del Torchio, who brings a wealth of experience in running high profile businesses and a track
record of approximately 45 years in managing industrial companies. Management has consistently
demonstrated its ability to develop our business by anticipating market trends and dynamics, creating
significant added value for customers and entering new geographies and product markets, underpinned by
clear and simple reporting lines directly to the Chief Operating Officer, who is supported by two regional
managers for the Americas and the Asia Pacific region, and by decentralized local sale structure with a
strong network of area managers responsible for day-to-day relationships with local customers. Our
effective management structure has also allowed us to take swift action in response to the weak global
economic environment in past years, including headcount reductions, temporary plant shutdowns and exits
from non-core markets, and in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. In recent years, management has
continued to implement cost reduction measures and to improve cash flow management while pursuing
our strategy to enter new geographies and product markets through organic growth and by acquiring and
successfully integrating companies already operating in our industry.

**Business strategy**

We aim to maintain our market leadership as a large-scale producer of specialty closures and to
continue growing our business while enhancing our profitability by growing our revenue, reducing our cost
base and expanding our product portfolio. Our strategy to achieve these objectives includes the following
key elements:

**_Continue to invest in product development and digitalization and cross-sell or up-sell high end products to existing_**
**_customers_**

Competition in our key market segments is focused mainly on product quality, innovation,
digitalization, sustainability and customer service. As a result, we believe that developing reliable products
with innovative functional features, aesthetic appeal and other improvements are necessary for enhancing
demand for our products. We plan to continue improving our product offering technologically and
innovatively by developing new ranges of safety closures that offer varying degrees of protection against
counterfeiting while promoting our customers’ brand images worldwide. In particular, we plan to continue
to focus on the digitalization of our closures by offering more products equipped with innovative
technological features, such as NFC microchips and quick response (“QR”) code-based solutions. We will
continue to work closely with our customers to develop new and more innovative solutions and we believe
that the increasing digitalization of closures will lead to even closer integration with our customers’
end-products and will position us for further growth. In addition, we intend to develop new aesthetically
appealing styles to complement existing products and meet the growing marketing requirements of our
customers. We also intend to encourage customers of our roll-on closures to upgrade and convert to more
sophisticated, aesthetic, luxurious and protective safety closures where appropriate. In order to refresh our
current product portfolio and meet the increasing demand for customized products, our research and
development team is currently developing a new series of products tailored for individual brands and
equipped with innovative technological and sustainable solutions and with a sophisticated design, which we
expect to launch between 2021 and 2023.

**_Increase sales of premium products through a focus on safety and luxury closures across different geographies_**

In recent years, we have expanded our global presence and we believe we are the leading producer of
safety closures by volume in several emerging markets, including Colombia, India, Mexico and Ukraine. In
2019, we started our operations in Africa following the inauguration of Guala Closures East Africa’s new
facility in Kenya and opened a new facility in Belarus. In 2020, we entered the Turkish market following
our acquisition of Closurelogic GmbH and its assets in Turkey. We intend to continue our geographical
expansion by consolidating our presence in these and other markets, with a particular focus on specialty
closures for the spirits market, including added-value safety and luxury closures.

According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, the global spirits
closures market has grown at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2% between 2016 and


10


-----

2019, reaching approximately 37 billion closures in 2019, of which approximately 18 billion units in our key
focus regions of India, Russia, the United States, the United Kingdom, Poland, Ukraine and Mexico.
According to this study, the market for safety closures represented approximately 38% of the global spirits
closures market in 2019, while 42% was represented by roll-on closures. Despite the negative impact from
the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in a 9% decrease in the size of the spirits closures market in our
key focus regions in 2020, a strong rebound is expected in 2021, with a full recovery predicted to occur
between 2021 and 2022, on a country-by-country basis. In particular, it is expected that the global spirits
closures market will grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2.5% between 2021 and
2024, mainly driven by growth in the safety and luxury closures markets, which are expected to grow at a
compound annual growth rate of approximately 4% and 5%, respectively, between 2021 and 2024.

We expect significant growth for the specialty closures segments in emerging markets. In recent years,
these markets have experienced an increase in the consumption of branded spirits. We believe this has
resulted in a greater demand for sophisticated anti-counterfeiting systems (such as our non-refillable safety
closures) by the producers of such spirits and we expect such demand to continue to grow. In addition,
producers are increasingly using safety closures as a marketing tool to create a premium brand image
through the use of exclusive packaging.

We believe that our leading position means that we are well placed to benefit from the expected
future growth in the safety closures market worldwide, including in emerging markets. We aim to take
advantage of this trend by sustaining or increasing our presence in these markets. We intend to achieve
this by strengthening our relationships with drinks producers and consolidating our presence and
infrastructure in the relevant countries.

**_Position the Group to benefit from expected growth in the market for wine closures and bottled water_**

According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, the aluminum
screwcaps for wine closures market grew at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 3% between
2016 and 2019, as a result of evolving consumer habits and the ability of screwcaps to preserve product
quality while having a low incidence on the price and costs of packaging. The screwcap market has also
demonstrated a higher resiliency to the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to the
overall closures market, showing a strong rebound in 2021 to date, which we expect will continue, and an
expected growth at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 3% between 2021 and 2024. We
believe that aluminum winecaps today account for approximately 23% of all bottled wine worldwide and
we believe that we are well positioned to capitalize on future growth in this industry, especially as large
regions such as North America and Europe move towards greater usage of aluminum winecaps.

We believe we are one of the top producers of aluminum winecap closures, with a market share by
volume of units sold in 2019 of approximately 30%. We expect growth in the wine closures market to
continue due to increasing end-consumer preference for aluminum closures rather than cork. We believe
that our leading position in this market means we are well placed to benefit from this growth. We aim to
take advantage of this trend by sustaining or increasing our presence this end-market, by strengthening our
relationships with wine producers, particularly those which are also active in the spirits market, by
developing new and aesthetically attractive closures, including closures with safety elements and innovative
features, and by consolidating our operations in the countries and regions where wine closures are
purchased in large volumes.

According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, the market for
closures for bottled water, measured by closures unit, grew at a compound annual growth rate of
approximately 5% between 2015 and 2019, and is expected to grow further a compound annual growth rate
of approximately 6% between 2021 and 2024, mainly driven by growth in population and increased shift
towards healthier beverages. In particular, the premium market for glass water bottles is expected to grow
at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 7% over the same timeframe. We believe we are
currently recognized as a key closure producer in the premium market for glass water bottles, particularly
following our acquisition of Closurelogic, a German manufacturer specializing in aluminum closures
mainly intended for the glass-bottle beverage and mineral water sector, in 2020. Going forward, we intend
to take advantage of these strong growth trends in the glass-bottle closures market by leveraging our core
business technology in metal screw caps for spirit closures as well as our expertise in tamper-evident
systems.


11


-----

**_Carry out further selected acquisitions in core and adjacent markets_**

During the last 10 years, we have grown both organically and through strategically identified
acquisitions. In doing so we have increased the number of geographical markets in which we operate (for
example, we established our presence in Australia, Bulgaria, France, Poland, South Africa, Ukraine,
Belarus, Germany and Turkey) and expanded our presence in new segments and the types of products
which we offer. More recently, in 2018, we acquired Guala Closures UCP, a Scottish company with a
long-standing presence in the Scottish market, and in 2020, we acquired Closurelogic GmbH, a German
manufacturer specialising in aluminum closures mainly intended for the glass-bottle beverage and mineral
water sector, as well as its Turkish subsidiary. In the same year, we also acquired a minority stake in
SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., an innovative technology services agency based in London focusing on
integrating hardware and software into connected packaging solutions. In the first quarter of 2021, we
increased our stake in SharpEnd Partnership Ltd. from 20% to 30%. We believe that we have been
successful at identifying and integrating acquired companies and at exploiting the synergies offered by such
acquisitions. Going forward, we intend to continue to identify appropriate expansion opportunities where
we consider it would help us grow in new geographical markets with high levels of alcohol consumption
that we view as underpenetrated including, for example, South Africa and certain countries in Asia. In
addition, we intend to continue to identify appropriate acquisitions and other development opportunities
that would allow us to consolidate our position in the market for aluminum and plastics closures, and
diversify our business through the expansion in the market for closures made of alternative materials such
as cork as well as in adjacent product markets, such as food and beverages, including water, beauty and the
pharmaceutical industries.

**_Further improve operational efficiency by optimizing manufacturing and the supply chain_**

The optimization and automation of our manufacturing processes and the investment in new
equipment for our technologically advanced plants is one of our core areas of focus and going forward we
expect to continue to invest in innovative technologies for supply chain management in order to optimize
our production and supply chain network efficiency. To further improve the efficiency of our production
processes, we aim to (i) modernize and automate our production processes on a wide-scale through our
flexible automation project, including for small and medium-sized product batches, which we believe will
enable us to respond promptly to evolving market needs; (ii) continue to advance our production processes
by implementing systems to monitor and improve our entire production cycles (the “continuous
improvement” program) and our multi-injection project aimed at eliminating the assembly stage of the
manufacturing process; and (iii) hedge part of the risks of price fluctuation in the purchase price of
aluminum through forward purchases on the London Metal Exchange through the use of hedging
depending on the commodity price environment. We endeavor to leverage key focus platforms across the
Group and improve profitability of selected sites opportunistically.

**_Continue prudent financial management, focusing on liquidity, deleveraging, Net Working Capital and hedging of_**
**_raw materials_**

We believe that the Group has benefited from prudent financial management throughout its history,
with a particular focus on cost reduction and cash flow management. We intend to use our cash flow
generation capacity, and our Revolving Credit Facility, to maintain appropriate levels of liquidity and Net
Working Capital in order to enable us to respond to unexpected changes in economic conditions. We will
continue to monitor our capital expenditures carefully in order to benefit from favorable economic
conditions and be able to take advantage of opportunities for acquisitions, and to continue to implement
the Group’s strategy, particularly in emerging markets. We will also continue to carefully monitor
fluctuations in the prices of raw materials, both aluminum and plastics, and changes in prevailing currency
exchange rates. We intend to manage raw material price fluctuations by hedging our exposures where
appropriate as well as currency fluctuations by matching revenue to expenditure in each currency where
possible.

**_The Sell-Out, Squeeze-Out and Delisting_**

As a result of SPSI holding more than 90% and less than 95% of Guala’s share capital, pursuant to
Article 108, paragraph 2 of the Italian Finance Law and taking into account that the purpose of the
Mandatory Offer was to achieve the Delisting of Guala, on June 11, 2021, SPSI announced that it would
purchase shares from any minority shareholders at a price of €8.20 per ordinary share tendered making a
request to such effect (the “Sell-Out”). The Sell-Out commenced on June 18, 2021 and will be completed
on July 8, 2021. If, as a result of the Sell-Out, SPSI comes to own at least 95% of the share capital of
Guala, SPSI will then exercise its right to purchase from minority shareholders all of their residual shares
in Guala (the “Squeeze-Out”) pursuant to Article 111, paragraph 1 of the Italian Finance Law. Following
completion of the Sell-Out, Guala’s ordinary shares and Market Warrants will be delisted from the
_Mercato Telematico Azionario organized and managed by Borsa Italiana S.p.A. (the “Delisting”). Upon_
completion of the Sell-Out and the Delisting, the Market Warrants will no longer be exercisable by their
respective holders, except in case of re-listing of the Issuer’s ordinary shares on the Italian Stock Exchange
(Mercato Telematico Azioniario).

**_The Refinancing_**

As a result of the Offers, the results of which were announced by SPSI on June 7, 2021, the change of
control provision in our Existing Notes was triggered and the Issuer will be required in accordance with the

Issuer elects to redeem all of the outstanding Existing Notes at par prior to the date on which the Issuer is

We intend to use a portion of the proceeds from the Offering to redeem the Existing Notes and pay

and unpaid interest thereon. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility”.
