**Principal factors affecting our results of operations**

**_General macroeconomic conditions and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic_**

We are impacted by global economic conditions, including in consumer spending resulting from,
among other factors, reduced consumer confidence, falling gross domestic product, rising unemployment
rates and uncertainty in the macroeconomic environment. Since early 2020, the worldwide outbreak of
COVID-19 and the consequent restrictive measures implemented by the public authorities of the affected
countries has had an enormous social impact and a significant impact on general economic performance
and on consumption and investments, leading to general uncertainty. We acted immediately to implement
all actions necessary to minimize the social and occupational health and safety and financial impacts by
defining and implementing flexible and timely action plans. From the outset, we worked tirelessly to ensure
the utmost health and safety for our employees, customers and suppliers. We immediately implemented a
series of protective measures for our personnel, investing in personal protective equipment to ensure that
activities are carried out in accordance with best practices in terms of occupational safety.

Our priority is and will remain ensuring the safety of our employees and business continuity. We
quickly and responsibly took all steps and safety measures identified by the authorities in the various
markets, introducing new protocols, work practices and safety precautions. These safety and prevention
measures introduced at the onset of the pandemic remain in place and are continuously updated to comply
with the new directives issued by the competent authorities. We also liaise continuously key business
partners such as suppliers and customers has been further ramped up with the aim of ensuring business
continuity. Specific business continuity plans have been prepared with our key customers. In addition to
the measures taken to prevent the spread of COVID-19, such as the distribution of disposable masks and
gloves, social distancing between workers, measuring body temperature when entering the workplace and
the sanitisation of all premises every two weeks, we entered into a COVID-19 insurance policy with AON,
a leading insurance company, covering all our workers worldwide. As part of our focus on the communities
in which we operate, we also began production of polycarbonate face shields in Luxembourg, which are
sold to businesses in order to finance the free supply of such face shields to healthcare structures in Italy,
Spain, France and Luxembourg.

To contain the spread, the governments of the various countries introduced increasingly restrictive
measures aimed at limiting movement and contact between people, as well as shutting down—sometimes
entirely—production activities in sectors classed as non-essential, allowing only essential activities and
production to continue, including those of the food, drinks and pharmaceuticals sector in which the group
operates, along with logistics services and transport. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, all of
our production facilities are operational.

Most of our production facilities continued to operate during the entirety of lockdown measures
imposed by the respective governments of the countries in which we operate in compliance with the
regulations for each country, as the type of activity carried out was classified among those that, except for
temporary bans imposed by local governments, could continue to operate during lockdowns. In particular,
all of our facilities in Europe remained operational in 2020 during the pandemic. Our facilities in Italy,
Spain and France were considered part of the essential supply chain, and remained operational throughout
the respective lockdowns. Our facilities in the United Kingdom and the newly acquired facility in Germany
also continued to operate throughout the lockdown at reduced capacities. The facilities in Eastern Europe
(i.e., Poland, Ukraine, Bulgaria and Belarus) continued to operate at full capacity. Our facilities in Asia
are among those that were most affected by the policies implemented by their respective governments to
contain the spread of the virus. Our facilities in India stopped operations on March 22, 2020 because of the
country’s total lockdown imposed by the local government and resumed operations on April 27, 2020 at
reduced capacity because of the national ban on the sale of alcohol until early May and the shuttering of
bars and restaurants until September, while the Chinese facility stopped during the period between
January 24, 2020 and February 14, 2020. Production at our facilities in the Americas was able to continue
during the entire pandemic, with the exception of Argentina where production was suspended for a limited

84


-----

period of time (March 20, 2020 to April 1, 2020), pending authorization to continue activities necessary for
the essential supply chain. Our facilities in California (U.S.) and Mexico continued to operate as they are
essential to the supply chain, and at sustained rates due to the growth in volumes for brands focused on
off-premises and e-commerce sales, which accelerated as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Chilean
facility also continued to operate at full capacity and, in Brazil, operations never stopped since the
government authorities have not implemented any lockdown measures. In Colombia, during the lockdown
period from March 20, 2020 to May 11, 2020, production was converted to produce closures for
disinfectants. The production of closures for spirits subsequently resumed, although sales volumes were
depressed by the closure of public places of business by local government order until September, 2020. In
Oceania, our facilities in Australia and New Zealand continued to operate as they are considered part of
essential supply chains. In Africa, our facility in Kenya continued to operate and no local lockdowns were
imposed on manufacturing activities, while the facility in South Africa was partially operational and, during
the lockdown period from March 26, 2020 to April 30, 2020, only produced for the Water & Beverage and
Pharma markets, which the South African government had classified as part of the essential supply chain.
Conversely, production was suspended for the spirits market during that period.

Our business was only marginally impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic in the first quarter of 2020,
when the impact was limited to operations in India, China, Argentina and South Africa, where operations
were ordered to temporarily shut down, as described above. In the second quarter of 2020, the impact of
the COVID-19 pandemic was significant, with a loss of sale volumes mainly in our operations in: (i) India,
where the government imposed a full lockdown of the country between March 22, 2020 and April 27, 2020
and banned the sale of alcohol from the end of March to the start of May with the shuttering of bars and
restaurants until September 2020; (ii) the United Kingdom, where operations are mainly geared more
towards global brands and the duty free market; (iii) South Africa, where the partial closure of the
facilities between March 26, 2020 and April 30, 2020 meant that it was only possible to produce limited
quantities for small niches of the mineral water and beverage markets and the pharmaceutical sector since
the sale of alcohol was banned from March 27 to June 1, 2020 and from July 12 to August 17, 2020; (iv)
Colombia, where production was converted during the March 20 to May 11, 2020 lockdown to produce
closures for disinfectants and public places of business remained shuttered until September 2020; (v) Spain
and Italy, which were the European countries hit the hardest by the COVID-19 pandemic. In the second
half of 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic continued to impact our business, but less so than in the second
quarter and the effects remained mostly concentrated in India, Spain, Italy and Colombia.

In terms of our end-markets, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic was felt most heavily in the
spirits market, being the sector with the greatest exposure to consumption in the distribution channel
represented by bars and restaurants, where net revenue decreased by €55.5 million, or 13.8%, from
€402.3 million in 2019 to €346.8 million in 2020 and Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates decreased
by €31.5 million, or 7.8%, from €402.3 million in 2019 to €370.7 million in 2020. Severe social distancing
restrictions resulted in the almost complete closure of the on-premises channel in the second quarter of
2020 and, in certain countries, in the third quarter as well. The strict limits to travel also adversely affected
sales through the duty free channel. Restrictive measures were eased towards the end of the second
quarter of 2020, with local governments gradually lifting shuttering orders on the HORECA industries in
the third quarter of 2020, but certain restrictions continue to remain in place in certain geographies. Near
the end of 2020, as cases rose again in Europe, local authorities ordered new containment measures, which
included another round of restrictions on the HORECA industries and the travel sector.

We were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic both in terms of decreased sales volumes and in terms
of additional costs to ensure the safety of facilities and employees and lower production efficiency as a
result of ensuring compliance with safety and social distancing requirements. These were partly offset by
measures to contain personnel expense, lower travel expenses and government assistance. We incurred
costs directly attributable to the COVID-19 pandemic, which primarily relate to purchasing personal
protective equipment (“PPE”) for employees, sanitization and the adaptation of work areas to comply with
social distancing requirements. In response to the decrease in sales volumes, we began introducing
measures to contain personnel expense in the second quarter of 2020 in order to limit the effect on the
profit margin, which resulted in a decrease in personnel expense, mainly in those European countries hit
the hardest by the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly the United Kingdom, where the furlough schemes
introduced by the government of the United Kingdom allowed us to reduce production on commensurate
basis with the lower sales volumes, and in Spain and in Italy, where production was optimized by
scheduling holiday leave for employees, concentrating production on the weekdays, avoiding production
during the weekend and curtailing bonuses. In India and South Africa, where the extremely severe April

85


-----

lockdowns imposed by the respective governments resulted in a shutdown of approximately one month,
personnel expense did not decrease in proportion to the drop in volumes as we also bore the personnel
expense during the shutdown period, pursuant to local regulations. We were, however, able to reduce
personnel expense in these countries, primarily due to the lower use of temporary workers in India and to
fewer overtime hours worked, the greater use of holiday leave and the decrease in employee numbers in
South Africa. In China, personnel expense fell as a result of the government’s reduction in social security
contributions and the smaller workforce as seven employees resigned during our suspension of between
January 24 and February 14, 2020. In Colombia, which was the country where our operations were
impacted the most in the South American region, we were able to achieve savings on personnel expense
due to the use of holiday leave and the relief granted by the Colombian government which suspended
social security contributions for two months. We also received assistance to decrease personnel expense in
the United Kingdom, Bulgaria and Argentina, reductions in social security contributions in China and
liquidity support measures, particularly the postponement of the deadline for payment of indirect taxes
such as VAT in the United Kingdom and the reduction of the VAT rate from 19% to 16% in Germany
from July to December 2020.

Following a more challenging second quarter in 2020, sales on a like-for-like basis and at constant
exchange rates recovered in the third quarter and grew in the fourth quarter of 2020 as the economic
impact of the COVID-19 pandemic started to ease. As a result, while our net revenue in 2020 decreased by
€34.5 million, or 5.7%, to €572.0 million from €606.5 million in 2019, our Net Revenue at Constant
Exchange Rates in 2020 decreased by only €2.7 million, or 0.4%, to €603.8 million from €606.5 million in
2019.

In the first quarter of 2021, the restrictions implemented in response to the COVID-19 pandemic in
the HORECA industries had a significant negative effect on the European water and beverage sector
(particularly in Italy, Spain and Germany), which heavily relies on on-premises consumption, and we
estimate that this resulted in a reduction in volumes impacting our net revenue by approximately €8 million
in such period. However, this loss was more than offset by increased sales volumes generated outside of
Europe, particularly in the Americas, where revenues grew steadily in the spirits and wine markets, and in
Asia, where revenues grew despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Sales volumes outside of
Europe also benefitted from customers increasing their safety stocks of end-products and higher demand
on off-premises channels such as supermarkets and e-commerce. As a result, while our net revenue for the
first quarter of 2021 decreased by €7.6 million, or 5.2%, to €138.3 million from €145.9 million for the first
quarter of 2020, our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates for the first quarter of 2021 increased by
€1.3 million, or 0.9% to €147.2 million from €145.9 million for the first quarter of 2020.

We expect that the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact our operations. See also “Risks
_Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—The COVID-19 pandemic could continue to have an adverse impact_
_on our business, financial condition, liquidity, and results of operations, which may be material and” and_
“Summary—Recent Developments—Impact of COVID-19”.

**_Volume/Mix and Selling Prices_**

Our sales are impacted by changes in the volumes sold based on the different sales mix in product
families and customers from one year to another. Certain of our products generate higher sales prices per
unit volume and increases in sales of those products impact our average sales price volume unit sold. In
particular, we generate the highest sales prices from sales of our specialty closures. In the periods under
review, we have focused on increasing our portion of sales from products that have higher sales prices in
order to support our margins. This policy contributed to the positive volume/mix effect of €12.0 million in
2020 and €7.3 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite the impact of the COVID-19
pandemic. We calculate the volume/mix effect by consolidating period-on-period decreases and increases
in sales volumes and changes in product mix (by product families and customers). In our calculation of the
volume/mix effect, we also include the currency effect generated by the translation of sales invoiced in a
currency other than the local reporting currency, by using the exchange rates of the relevant prior period.

**_Fluctuations in currency exchange rates_**

We operate worldwide and have significant non-euro denominated assets, liabilities, revenue and
costs. The Group is exposed to currency risk, particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar,
pounds sterling, Australian dollar, Indian rupee, Ukrainian hryvnia and Polish złoty against the euro, our
Group’s reporting currency, as well as against the local reporting currency of each of our subsidiaries. In

86


-----

the year ended December 31, 2020, we derived 15%, 13%, 9% and 5% of our net revenue from sales in
U.S. dollars, pounds sterling, Indian rupees and Australian dollars, respectively. We also have exposure to
other currencies such as the Brazilian real, Mexican peso, Colombian peso, Argentine peso, South African
rand and New Zealand dollar. Certain of these currencies have experienced considerable volatility against
the euro in recent years which has affected our results of operations.

For example, our reported results of operations were significantly impacted by negative translation
effects of the appreciation of the euro in 2020 and in the first quarter of 2021. By way of example to
illustrate and quantify the impact of currency exchange rates on our results of operations that was
significant over the periods under review, if we applied the average exchange rate of the currencies
relevant to our business for the year ended December 31, 2019 to the year ended December 31, 2020, our
Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates was €603.8 million (as compared to net revenue of
€572.0 million as reported) and our Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates was €104.2 million (as
compared to Adjusted EBITDA €98.0 million as reported), respectively. In addition, our Net Revenue at
Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been €147.2 million (as
compared to net revenue of €138.3 million as reported) and our Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange
Rates was €26.6 million (as compared to Adjusted EBITDA €24.3 million as reported), respectively.

The foregoing impact on our results of operations is mainly due to the translation effect of non-euro
revenues generated during the periods and the appreciation of the euro, particularly against the British
pound sterling, the Indian rupee, the Ukrainian hryvnia, the Argentinian peso and the Mexican peso. See
“Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Measures”.

_Transaction risk_

Our exchange rate transaction risks principally relate to purchases of raw materials such as plastic
resin and aluminum which have underlying global commodity price indexes denominated in U.S. dollars
and are used to varying degrees in the production of all of our products. Our other fixed costs, such as
energy, personnel and services related to production are typically denominated in the currency of the
relevant production facility (e.g., euro for Italy, złoty for Poland, Brazilian real for Brazil, etc.).
Additionally, our customer contracts are typically payable in the currency of the country where the
contract is signed, even if the customer may sell spirits or wine for a worldwide consumer base. By locating
production in many countries where our customers are based, we seek to match our operating costs with
operating revenue in each of the major currencies in which we operate. To the extent that we have
incurred expenses that are not denominated in the same currency as related revenue, exchange rate
fluctuations have in some cases caused our expenses to increase or decrease as a percentage of total
revenue. We also utilize of derivatives to manage movement in aluminum commodity prices. See “—Costs
_for raw materials”._

_Translation Risk_

Our currency translation risk is primarily related to the recognition of revenue generated by
subsidiaries during our period-end consolidation and reporting. To prepare the consolidated financial
statements of the Group, we translate assets, liabilities, total revenue and expenses into euro at applicable
exchange rates. To determine the applicable exchange rate, we use the average exchange rate for
statement of comprehensive income items for the period in which we are reporting and the spot
period-end exchange rate for balance sheet items. See note 2(d) to the 2020 Financial Statements, as well
as the other financial information contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and “—Critical
_accounting policies” below. Both revenue and expenses that are denominated in foreign currency are_
converted into euro at the spot rates of the days on which they are recorded. In order to assist
management to identify trends and compare performance across regions and business units, we report Net
Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates and Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates basis which is
prepared translating the results of a given period in a particular local currency applying the average
exchange rate of the local currency in the same period of the previous year.

**_Costs for raw materials_**

€263.7 million of our costs in 2019, €243.4 million of our costs in 2020 and €61.5 million in the three
months ended March 31, 2021 were related to raw materials. Raw material costs accounted for 43.5% of
our net revenue in 2019, 42.5% of our net revenue in 2020 and 44.4% of our net revenue in the three
months ended March 31, 2021. The principal raw materials used in our manufacturing processes are plastic

87


-----

resins and aluminum. We used a total of 35,481 tons of aluminum in 2020 and consumed more than 43,000
tonnes of different types of plastic (PE, PP, PS, PC, PET, etc.). Plastic resins and aluminum accounted for
€15.9 million and €26.5 million, or approximately 26% and 43%, respectively, of the cost of all raw
materials purchased in the three months ended March 31, 2020; €61.2 million and €110.9 million, or
approximately 25% and 46%, respectively, of the cost of all raw materials purchased in 2020 and
€79.1 million and €110.7 million, or approximately 30% and 42%, respectively, of the cost of all raw
materials purchased in 2019.

Raw materials prices can fluctuate substantially over relatively short periods of time. Plastic resins are
subject to substantial price fluctuations resulting from shortages in supply and changes in the prices of
natural gas, crude oil and other petrochemical products from which resins are produced as well as other
factors. Aluminum prices generally exhibit less fluctuation than plastic resins. The price of aluminum has
trended upward in recent years. Aluminum prices on the demand-side are driven by end users from the
construction, transportation (mainly automotive) and consumer (largely packaging) industries.

As we do not typically enter into long-term committed contracts with customers, our contractual
arrangements with customers do not contain pass-through mechanisms that would allow or require us to
make periodic adjustments in prices to account for commodity price fluctuations. As a result of the
foregoing dynamics, generally, any increase in the prices of our raw materials has a direct impact on our
production costs and operating margins unless we are able to raise prices. We believe that the relevant raw
material prices to illustrate price trends are the LME/ton price for aluminum and for plastic resins, the
high density polyethylene (“HDPE”) price and polypropylene and homopolymer price in Europe and the
HDPE price and polystyrene price in India. See “Industry Overview”.

By way of illustration, in the first three months of 2021, the average prices of plastic resins (HDPE
Europe) increased by 10.7% and aluminum prices increased by 12.4%, in each case compared to the first
three months of 2020. In 2020, the average prices of plastic resins (HDPE Europe) decreased by 12.1%
and aluminum prices decreased by 6.5%, in each case compared to 2019, and in 2019, the average prices of
plastic resins increased (HDPE Europe) by 1.7% and the price of aluminum decreased by 9.7% in each
case compared to 2018. These increases and decreases contributed to corresponding changes in our total
costs. We manage this exposure vis-à-vis customers through proactive renegotiation of prices with
customers when raw material prices put pressure on our margins and rely on our long track record of
delivering innovative new products and extracting efficiencies through reduction of raw material use to
maintain, and even modestly raise, prices during low-commodity periods. Sales of closures are based on
contracts and/or purchase orders that mean that at least part of any increase in the prices of raw materials
can be transferred to our customers, when the contracts provide for periodic price adjustments. If this is
not possible, we are able to manufacture similar closures due to our technological expertise using different
materials mix that ensures, nonetheless, product quality. Given our wide product range, we can offer
customers various solutions (using different materials) and to direct their choices to the higher value
added luxury lines, thus better absorbing any raw material price increases without significantly affecting
margins.

We also employ commodity derivatives for aluminum to hedge a certain portion of purchases. On
average, 15% of our aluminum costs in the year ended December 31, 2020 and in the three months ended
March 31, 2021 were related to purchases of aluminum ingots on the London Metal Exchange, through
forward contracts and spot transactions, while the remaining aluminum costs consist primarily of costs
incurred in conversion and processing which are typically contractually fixed for a short period of time. As
we typically purchase aluminum based on contracts that set prices by reference to the aluminum quotations
on the London Metal Exchange in U.S. dollars, which are converted into euro at the average exchange rate
at the month of purchase, we seek to reduce our exposure to the risks associated with aluminum price
fluctuations by entering into forward contracts with brokers operating on the London Metal Exchange,
whereby we purchase aluminum at a fixed price to protect our operating margins from price volatility. We
have not historically hedged the risk of fluctuations in the purchase price of plastics as these raw materials
are not listed on international markets. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Our business is
_subject to fluctuations in the price and availability of raw materials” and note 38(b) to the 2020 Financial_
Statements.

Other methods of commodity risk mitigation include the careful selection of our suppliers, in
particular for plastics, where we seek out suppliers that match our pricing, quality and reliability of supply
criteria. We have not experienced any significant difficulties over the past few years in obtaining sufficient
quantities of the raw materials required for our production. We also continually seek to implement
innovative product and process solutions aimed at reducing consumption of raw materials.

**_Demand and activity levels in the spirits and wine end-markets_**

We sell our products primarily to customers operating in the spirits and wine end-markets in various
geographies around the world. In the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended
December 31, 2020, these markets combined represented 84% and 81%, respectively, of our net revenue.
Accordingly, our sales volumes and results of operations depend to a significant extent on the level of
activity and industry trends in these end-markets.

For spirits producers, packaging and brand are key elements in product identification and
differentiation. As a result, demand in this end-market is primarily focused on high quality, customized
and reliable products that enable customers to better differentiate and position their brands against their
competitors. We believe that demand for safety closures in the spirits end-market will continue to grow,
particularly in emerging countries where premium brands are penetrating further and where the risk of
counterfeiting is higher.

Technological solutions, sustainability and zero-environmental impact packaging are also becoming
increasingly important in both the spirits and wine end-markets. Spirits and wine producers as well as their
end-customers are increasingly looking for products with fully integrated technological functionalities that
enhance product safety and customer experience, as well as products with a reduced impact on the
environment, that are recyclable and made with a higher share of recycled materials. We believe that these
will be the key growth and demand trends for our products in the spirits and wine end-markets going
forward.

**_The overall level of, and the interest rates payable on, our indebtedness_**

During the periods under review, we had significant debt service obligations related to the Existing
Notes. As of March 31, 2021, our current and non-current financial liabilities amounted, respectively, to
€24.4 million and €504.4 million, for a total amount of €528.9 million, and, excluding unamortized
transaction costs and the put option liability in respect of non-controlling investors and financial liabilities
related to the Market Warrants, our total financial liabilities amounted to €500.9 million. For information
relating to the interest rates payable on our financial indebtedness, see note 30 to the 2020 Financial
Statement and note 24 to the Unaudited Interim Financial Statements. Prior to and following the
Refinancing, we had and will continue to have a significant amount of indebtedness. As of March 31, 2021,
As Adjusted Total Financial Debt would have been €525.7 million (excluding unamortized transaction
costs, the put option liability in respect of non-controlling investors, financial liabilities related to the
Market Warrants and any amounts that we may draw under the Revolving Credit Facility in connection
with the Refinancing). See “Capitalization”.

**_Seasonal factors_**

Our results of operations are affected by seasonal factors for certain product categories (specifically,
roll-on for wine closures and roll-on closures for mineral water), which generally results in an increase in
the sales volumes in the second half of each year and, especially, during holiday periods, which also vary
according to hemisphere. Our sales particularly correspond to variations relating to consumption and/or
production of wine in such regions. Accordingly, our quarterly results of operations will vary from quarter
to quarter due to these seasonal factors, and do not contribute evenly to the annual results.

**_Net revenue_**

Net revenue decreased by €7.6 million, or 5.2%, from €145.9 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2020 to €138.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021. Our Net Revenue at

91


-----

Constant Exchange Rates increased by €1.3 million, or 0.9% from €145.9 million for the first quarter of
2020 to €147.2 million. The negative translation impact on net revenue in the first three months of 2021
was €(8.9) million, which was due to the appreciation of the Euro against almost all currencies with which
the Group operates. The change in the consolidation perimeter from the first quarter of 2020 to the first
quarter of 2021 impacted net revenue by €0.1 million, which represents the net effect from the
consolidation of Closurelogic’s assets acquired in February 2020 in Germany and in September 2020 in
Turkey (an increase in net revenue of €2.1 million) and the sale of GCL Pharma in April 2020 (a decrease
in net revenue of €2.2 million). The contribution to turnover as a result of this change in the consolidation
scope as compared to the three months ended March 31, 2021 is not material.

The increase in Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021
was mainly due the positive volumes/mix effect of €7.3 million and the benefit of €1.8 million generated by
our price increase policy. The increase in sales volumes was concentrated in the Americas, where revenues
grew steadily in the spirits and wine markets, and Asia, where revenues grew despite the impact of the
COVID-19 pandemic. These trends more than offset the impact on our net revenue of approximately
€7.9 million as a result of an estimated reduction in sales volumes in the European water and beverages
sector, which has been negatively affected by the restrictions implemented in the HORECA industries in
response to the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly in Italy, Spain and Germany, as well as lower volumes in
Oceania.

_Safety Closures_

Revenue from safety closures decreased by €1.6 million, or 2.9%, from €54.6 million for the three
months ended March 31, 2020 to €53.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, which was

92


-----

mainly due to a negative translation impact of €(5.1) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange
Rates from safety closures increased by €3.5 million, or 6.4%, to €58.2 million from €54.6 million for the
three months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was mainly due to higher sales volumes in the Americas
and Asia, which more than offset lower sales volumes in Europe.

_Luxury Closures_

Revenue from luxury closures decreased by €0.4 million, or 5.2%, from €7.7 million for the three
months ended March 31, 2020 to €7.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, which was
mainly due to a negative translation impact of €(0.6) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange
Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 from luxury closures increased by €0.2 million, or 2.5%,
to €7.9 million from €7.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The slight increase was
mainly due to higher sales volumes in the Mexico, which were almost entirely offset by lower sales volumes
in Europe.

_Roll-on Closures_
Revenue from roll-on closures decreased by €4.6 million, or 9.4%, from €48.8 million for the three
months ended March 31, 2020 to €44.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, with a negative
translation impact of €(2.1) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months
ended March 31, 2021 from roll-on closures decreased by €2.5 million, or 5.2%, to €46.3 million from
€48.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly due to lower sales as a
result of the restrictions implemented in the HORECA industries in response to the COVID-19 pandemic,
which mostly impacted the water & beverages market in Europe, particularly Italy, Spain and Germany.

_Roll-on for Wine Closures_

Revenue from the sale of roll-on for wine closures increased by €1.2 million, or 4.3%, from
€28.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €29.3 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2021, despite negative translation impact of €(0.8) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant
Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 from wine closures increased by €2.1 million,
or 7.4%, to €30.1 million from €28.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was
mainly due to higher sales volumes in Poland, the Americas and Germany, where we started to operate in
February 2020, which were partly offset by lower sales volumes in Oceania and the United Kingdom.

_Other Revenue_

Other revenue decreased by €2.2 million, or 32.8%, from €6.7 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2020 to €4.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, with a negative translation impact
of €(0.3) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021
from other closures decreased by €1.9 million or 29%, to €4.7 million from €6.7 million for the three months
ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly due to the sale of GCL Pharma in April 2020.

_Europe_

Net revenue from operations in Europe decreased by €11.1 million, or 12.2%, from €91.2 million for
the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €80.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, with
a negative translation impact of €(2.4) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three
months ended March 31, 2021 of this region decreased by €8.7 million, or 9.6%, to €82.5 million from
€91.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease is mainly due to the negative
impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the first three months of 2021, due to the restrictions implemented
in the HORECA industries, especially in Spain, Italy and Germany. In particular, the total decrease in net
revenue generated in these three countries accounted for €8.8 million in the first three months of 2021.

_Americas_

Net revenue from operations in the Americas increased by €3.5 million, or 14.4%, from €24.3 million
for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €27.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021,
despite a significant negative translation impact of €(4.9) million, recorded mainly in Mexico, Argentina
and Brazil. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months ended March 31, 2021 of this
region increased by €8.4 million, or 34.6%, to €32.7 million from €24.3 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2020. The increase is mainly due to the positive net impact on sales volumes from the
COVID-19 pandemic in the three months ended March 31, 2021, which was driven primarily by customers
increasing their safety stocks of end-products and higher demand on off-premises channels such as
supermarkets and e-commerce, particularly in North America, which more than offset the negative impact
on volumes due to the restrictions implemented in response to the pandemic, including in the in
HORECA industries.

_Asia_

Net revenue from operations in Asia increased by €0.5 million, or 2.9%, from €17.2 million for the
three months ended March 31, 2020 to €17.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a
significant negative translation impact of €(1.6) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the
three months ended March 31, 2021 of this region increased by €2.1 million, or 12.5%, to €19.3 million
from €17.2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The increase is mainly due to revenues
growing in the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020
when they were already partially impacted by COVID-19. The estimated net impact of the COVID-19
pandemic in Asia was immaterial.

_Oceania_

Net revenue from operations in Oceania decreased by €0.8 million, or 8.8%, from €9.1 million for the
three months ended March 31, 2020 to €8.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a
positive translation impact of €0.5 million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three months
ended March 31, 2021 of this region decreased by €1.3 million or 13.8%, to €7.9 million from €9.1 million
for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The decrease is mainly due to the decrease in sales volumes
resulting from the slow-down of the domestic wine market, the steady increase in exports of bulk wine and
the recent reduction in wine exports to China. These factors have resulted in a supply surplus in the region,
which led to greater competition and downward pressure on sales prices. In light of these negative trends,

94


-----

we started the process of reorganizing our business in Australia in order to align its ongoing costs with the
changed market conditions, including by reducing headcount.

_Africa_

Net revenue from operations in Africa increased by €0.3 million, or 7.3%, from €4.1 million for the
three months ended March 31, 2020 to €4.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a
negative translation impact of €(0.4) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates in the three
months ended March 31, 2021 of this region increased by €0.7 million or 17.8%, to €4.8 million from
€4.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. The increase is mainly due to the positive net
impact on sales volumes due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the three months ended March 31, 2021,
compared to a negative impact in the three months ended March 31, 2020. This positive net impact was
mainly due to customers increasing their safety stocks of end-products and higher demand on off-premises
channels such as supermarkets and e-commerce, which more than offset the negative impact on volumes
due to the restrictions implemented in response to the pandemic, including in the HORECA industries.

**_Internal work capitalized_**

previous tax losses.

**_Loss for the period_**

98


-----

revenue, loss decreased from 4.3% in the first three months of 2020 to 0.4% in the first three months of 2021.
This decrease was mainly due to higher EBITDA (€0.2 million), lower net financial expense (€(3.5) million),
lower amount of amortization and depreciation (€(0.6) million) as well as lower taxes (€(1.5) million).

**_EBIT_**

EBIT increased by €0.8 million, or 10.5%, from €7.1 million for the three months ended March 31,
2020 to €7.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021. EBIT margin increased from 4.9% in the
three months ended March 31, 2020 to 5.7% in the three months ended March 31, 2021. This increase was
primarily due to higher sales volumes in the Americas, positive volume/mix effects and the increase in
average sales price in Europe, South America and Africa, coupled with the decrease in costs for raw
materials due to the profitable management of strategic raw materials procurement (particularly
aluminum purchases), as well as the achievement of economies of scale in the United Kingdom, Asia and
Latin America as a result of greater efficiency and the reorganization of our production factors. These
factors more than offset the reduction in sales volumes due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the
end-markets that were most affected by the ongoing restrictions on the HORECA industries, particularly
the European water and beverage sector, as well as the higher purchase price of strategic raw materials,
such as aluminum.

**_Adjusted EBITDA_**

Adjusted EBITDA increased by €0.2 million, or 0.8%, from €24.1 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2020 to €24.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021, despite a decrease of
€(2.3) million due to the negative translation impact following the appreciation of the Euro against nearly
all currencies with which the Group operates. Our Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates
increased by €2.5 million, or 10.4%, in the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to the same
period in 2020. This increase was primarily due to higher sales volumes in the Americas and positive
volume/mix effects (€0.8 million), an increase in average sales price in Europe, South America and Africa
(€1.8 million), the profitable management of strategic raw materials procurement (particularly aluminum
purchases), as well as the achievement of economies of scale in the United Kingdom, Asia and Latin
America as a result of greater efficiency and the reorganization of our production factors (€3.0 million).
These factors more than offset the reduction in sales volumes due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the
end-markets that were most affected by the ongoing restrictions on the HORECA industries, particularly
the European water and beverage sector (€(1.1) million), as well as the higher purchase price of strategic
raw materials, such as aluminum (€(1.4) million).

Adjusted EBITDA margin for the three months ended March 31, 2021 was 17.5%, compared to
16.5% for the three months ended March 31, 2020.

The most significant variations affecting the main statement of profit or loss and other comprehensive
income captions for the periods under review are described below.

**_Net revenue_**

Net revenue decreased by €34.5 million, or 5.7%, from €606.5 million for the year ended December 31,
2019 to €572.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates
in 2020 decreased by €2.7 million, or 0.4%, from €606.5 million in 2019 to €603.8 million. The change in the
consolidation perimeter from 2019 to 2020 impacted net revenue by €23.7 million, which represents the net
effect from the consolidation of Closurelogic’s assets in 2020 (an increase in net revenue of €30.9 million), the
sale of the Spanish assets of the PET division in the second half of 2019 (a decrease in net revenue of €1.2
million) and the sale of GCL Pharma in April 2020 (a decrease in net revenue of €6.0 million). Excluding this
net effect, This decrease was primarily due to the effects of the global COVID-19 pandemic. Following a
more challenging second quarter, sales on a like-for-like basis and at constant exchange rates recovered in the
third quarter and grew in the fourth quarter.

In the year ended December 31, 2020, we recorded a positive volumes/mix effect of €12.0 million and
price increases generated a benefit of €4.9 million. However, these positive effects were fully offset by the
estimated impact of a loss of volumes due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

_Safety Closures_

Revenue from safety closures decreased by €52.4 million, or 20.4%, from €256.1 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 to €203.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, with a negative translation impact
of €(16.1) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates from safety closures in 2020 decreased by
€36.3 million, or 14.2%, to €219.8 million from €256.1 million in 2019, mainly as a consequence of the lower
sales following the outbreak of COVID-19, primarily due to its impact on the spirits market.

101


-----

_Luxury Closures_

Revenue from luxury closures decreased by €3.1 million, or 9.5%, from €32.8 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019 to €29.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, with a negative
translation impact of €(2.2) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates from luxury closures in
2020 decreased by only €0.8 million, or 2.6%, to €32.0 million from €32.8 million in 2019. The decrease in
revenue from luxury closures was mainly due to lower sales as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.

_Roll-on Closures_

Revenue from roll-on closures increased by €21.7 million, or 12.1%, from €179.3 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019 to €201.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, with a negative
translation impact of €(6.5) million. This increase was mainly due to the acquisition of Closurelogic’s assets
in 2020, which increased revenue from roll-on closures by €26.3 million.

_Roll-on for Wine Closures_

Revenue from the sale of roll-on for wine closures increased by €7.6 million, or 7.0%, from
€108.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €115.9 million for the year ended December 31,
2020, despite the negative translation impact of €(5.7) million. Our Net Revenue at Constant Exchange
Rates from roll-on for wine closures in 2020 increased by €13.3 million, or 12.3%, to €121.6 million from
€108.3 million in 2019, mainly as a consequence of the acquisition of Closurelogic’s assets in 2020, which
increased net revenue from roll-on for wine closures by €4.3 million, and the growth in sales in the United
Kingdom, Chile and North America.

_Other Revenue_
Other revenue decreased by €8.4 million, or 28.0%, from €30.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 to €21.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. The reduction is mainly due to
the sale of GCL Pharma in April 2020 and the sale of part of the PET business in 2019.

_Europe_

Net revenue from operations in Europe decreased by €12.9 million, or 3.6%, from €358.2 million for
the year ended December 31, 2019 to €345.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, with a
negative translation impact of €(6.1) million. The decrease is mainly due to the sale of some of the Spanish
assets of the PET division to third parties and the sale of GCL Pharma S.r.l. in the second quarter of 2020
and a decrease in sales as a result of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly in relation to
operations in the United Kingdom, Spain and Italy, which had a negative impact on our net revenue in
Europe. The decrease was only partially offset by the positive contribution of €30.9 million in revenue from
the acquisition of Closurelogic.

_Americas_

Net revenue from operations in the Americas increased by €2.7 million, or 2.5%, from €109.8 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €112.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, despite the
negative translation impact of €(18.4) million recorded, mainly in Mexico, Argentina and Brazil. Net
Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates of this region in 2020 increased by €21.1 million, or 19.2%, to
€130.8 million from €109.8 million in 2019. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in this region led to
significant growth in sales in the North American spirits market following the increase in off-premises
demand and penetration in new businesses/customers, which had a positive impact, in Mexico due to
greater sales in the U.S. market, which had a positive impact of €0.7 million, and the increase in sales in
the Chilean wine market.

_Asia_

Net revenue from operations in Asia decreased by €20.7 million, or 25.8%, from €80.1 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019 to €59.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Revenue at
Constant Exchange Rates of this region in 2020 decreased by €16.7 million, or 20.8%, to €63.5 million from
€80.1 million in 2019. This decrease is mainly due to the drop in sales after the shutdown of facilities in
India and China during the lockdown in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and operations that were at
less than full capacity in the subsequent months because of the contraction in domestic consumption
following the ban on the sale of alcohol between the end of March and the start of May and the shuttering
of bars and restaurants until September in India, causing an overall negative impact on sale volume in Asia
compared to 2019 of €17.2 million. In addition, the decrease was partially due to the transfer of some of
the volumes previously produced by our Indian subsidiary to the business start-up in Kenya.

_Oceania_

Net revenue from operations in Oceania decreased by €1.9 million, or 4.7%, from €40.1 million for
the year ended December 31, 2019 to €38.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, including the
negative translation impact of €(1.1) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates of this region in
2020 decreased by €0.8 million, or 1.9%, to €39.3 million from €40.1 million in 2019. Sales in this region are
mainly tied to the wine segment which has in recent years has been impacted by exports of unbottled wine
that is then bottled in the country of destination. The delay in the bottling season due to the COVID-19
pandemic has partly eroded sales volumes in 2020.

103


-----

_Africa_

Net revenue from operations in Africa decreased by €1.7 million, or 9.3%, from €18.3 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019 to €16.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, with a negative
translation impact of €(2.2) million. Net Revenue at Constant Exchange Rates of this region in 2020
increased by €0.5 million, or 2.6%, to €18.8 million from €18.3 million in 2019. The decrease in revenue
was also due to operations in South Africa and, in particular, the partial suspension of production from
March 26 to April 30 following the lockdown imposed by the local authorities and the ban on the sale of
alcohol between March 27 and June 1 and between July 12 and August 17. Specifically, production of
closures for the spirits market in South Africa was suspended by the South African government and
production was only allowed for the water & beverage and pharma markets that were designated as
essential, causing an overall negative impact of €(2.5) million. Despite the impact of the COVID-19
pandemic, operations in Kenya continue to grow at sustained rates, partly offsetting the downturn in South
Africa.

Personnel expense increased by €4.6 million, or 3.6%, from €125.3 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 to €129.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, mainly as a result of the net
impact from the change in the scope of consolidation from 2019 to 2020. Net personnel expense related to
the acquisition of Closurelogic net of the disposal of GCL Pharma increased personnel expense by
€7.2 million. Excluding this impact, personnel expense primarily due to the cost containment policies that
we implemented in the second and third quarters of 2020 to mitigate the impact of the lower sale volumes
on profitability following the global outbreak of COVID-19.

This resulted in a decrease in personnel expense, mainly in those European countries that experienced
more severe effects from the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly the United Kingdom, where the furlough
schemes introduced by the government of the United Kingdom allowed us to reduce production on
commensurate basis with the lower sales volumes, and in Spain and Italy, where production was optimized
by scheduling holiday leave for employees, concentrating production on the weekdays, avoiding production
during the weekend and curtailing bonuses.

In India and South Africa, where the extremely severe April lockdowns imposed by the respective
governments resulted in a shutdown of approximately one month, personnel expense did not decrease in
proportion to the drop in volumes as we also bore the personnel expense during the shutdown period,
pursuant to local regulations. We were, however, able to reduce personnel expense in these countries,
primarily due to the lower use of temporary workers in India and to fewer overtime hours worked, the

Income taxes decreased by €0.6 million, or 30.3%, from €2.1 million in 2019 to €1.5 million in 2020,
primarily due to lower current taxes, partly offset by the reduced reversal of deferred taxes. Current taxes
in 2020 decreased by €3.2 million as compared 2019 mainly due to our lower results because of the
COVID-19 pandemic, specifically in relation to our business in India. The reduction in current taxes in the
countries that experienced more severe effects from the COVID-19 pandemic was partly offset by an
increase in the current taxes payables by the Group where actual results increased in the year ended
December 31, 2020 compared to the year ended December 31, 2019, such as, for example, our operations
in Ukraine and United States.

The decrease in deferred taxes is primarily due to the smaller reversal of deferred taxes on the gains
recognized in connection with the purchase price accounting and, in particular, the one-time recognition in
2019 of the €4.0 million reversal of deferred taxes recognized on the gains that arose in connection with the
purchase price accounting for our operations in India following the reduction in the tax rate applicable in
India from 35% to 25%.

**_Profit (loss) for the year_**

Profit for the year of €14.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased by €20.6 million,
or 140.4%, to a loss of €5.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. As a percentage of net revenue,
profit decreased from 2.4% for the year ended December 31, 2019 to a loss of 1.0% for the year ended
December 31, 2020. This decrease is mainly due to the following effects: the contraction in the EBITDA
(loss) by €12.7 million, the increase in net financial expense by €6.7 million, including €4.5 million for
greater exchange losses as the euro appreciated against the other currencies in the regions in which we
operate) and the increase in amortization and depreciation of with a negative impact of €1.8 million, partly
offset by lower taxes with a positive impact of €0.6 million.

**_EBIT_**

EBIT decreased by €14.5 million, or 32.0%, from €45.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019
to €30.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. EBIT margin decreased from 7.5% of net revenue
for the year ended December 31, 2019 to 5.4% of net revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. This
decrease was mainly due to the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in additional
costs and lower production efficiency to ensure the safety of facilities and employees and comply with
safety and social distancing requirements, which was only partly offset by measures to contain personnel
expenses, lower travel expenses and government assistance.

**_Adjusted EBITDA_**

Adjusted EBITDA decreased by €15.6 million, or 13.7%, from €113.5 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 to €98.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, including the negative
translation impact of €(6.2) million following the appreciation of the euro against almost all other
currencies that we use in conducting our operations.

Adjusted EBITDA at Constant Exchange Rates decreased by €9.3 million, or 8.2%, in the year ended
December 31, 2020 compared to the year ended December 31, 2019, mainly due to the negative impact of
the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, sales volumes decreased and we
incurred additional costs to ensure the safety of employees and the safe operation of our facilities,
including lower production efficiency to ensure compliance with safety and social distancing requirements.
This impact was partly offset by measures to contain personnel expenses, lower travel expenses and
government assistance in certain of the jurisdictions in which we operate.

Adjusted EBITDA margin for the year ended December 31, 2020 was 17.1%, compared to 18.7% for
the year ended December 31, 2019 due to the dilution effect caused by the consolidation of Closurelogic’s
assets that we acquired in 2020.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Prior to the consummation of the Transactions, our historical liquidity requirements have arisen
primarily from the need to meet our debt service requirements, to finance our operations and to fund
capital expenditures, product research and development and acquisitions. We expect that these will
continue to be our primary liquidity requirements.

In connection with the Offers, the results of which were announced by SPSI on June 7, 2021, the
change of control provision in our Existing Notes were triggered and the Issuer will be required in
accordance with the provisions of the indenture governing the Existing Notes to make an offer to holders
of the Existing Notes to repurchase any or all of their Existing Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to
101% of the principal amount of such Existing Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional
amounts, if any, unless the Issuer elects to redeem all of the outstanding Existing Notes at par prior to the
date on which the Issuer is required to make such an offer. There is committed financing in place in order
to fund the redemption, if required. We will apply the proceeds from the issuance of the Notes to redeem
the Existing Notes and pay accrued interest thereon, to repay amounts outstanding under the Existing
Revolving Credit Facility, including any accrued and unpaid interest thereon, for general corporate
purposes and to pay fees and expenses associated with the Refinancing. See “Use of Proceeds”. Our

109


-----

primary sources of liquidity are cash flows from operations and borrowings from financial institutions
under our credit facilities, particularly the €80.0 million Revolving Credit Facility that will be entered into
in connection with the Transactions.

As of March 31, 2021, our current and non-current financial liabilities amounted, respectively, to
€24.4 million and €504.4 million, for a total amount of €528.9 million, and, excluding unamortized
transaction costs and the put option liability in respect of non-controlling investors and financial liabilities
related to the Market Warrants, our total financial liabilities amounted to €500.9 million. As of March 31,
2021, as adjusted for the Refinancing our As Adjusted Total Financial Debt would have been
€525.7 million (excluding unamortized transaction costs, the put option liability in respect of
non-controlling investors, financial liabilities related to the Market Warrants and any amounts that we may
draw under the Revolving Credit Facility in connection with the Refinancing).

From time to time we engage in the sale of our trade receivables on the basis of without-recourse
factoring arrangements in order to support our working capital and liquidity needs. The COVID-19
pandemic partly contributed to the decrease in trade receivables from €104.1 million as of December 31,
2019 to €92.6 million as of December 31, 2020 and €97.2 million as of March 31, 2021, which, in turn,
resulted in a reduction in the use of without-recourse factoring from €28.2 million as of December 31, 2019
to €26.7 million as of December 31, 2020 and €20.8 million as of March 31, 2021.

Our current and prospective liquidity is monitored constantly. We have not experienced any
significant changes in terms of collection or payment activities directly or indirectly related to the
COVID-19 pandemic. We believe that the available liquidity is adequate to cover current and prospective
operating needs and debt service obligations.

However, we face significant risks to our liquidity. For instance, our business may not generate
sufficient cash flows from operations or future debt and equity financing may not be available to us in an
amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including under the Notes, or to fund our other
liquidity needs. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility” and “Risk Factors—Risks
_Relating to our Indebtedness—We may not be able to generate sufficient cash to meet our debt obligations”._

We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity also include:

   - a reduction in operating cash flows due to a decline in EBIT from our operations, which could be
caused by a downturn in our performance or in the industry as a whole;

   - the failure of our customers to make payments due to us;

   - a delay by our customers to make payments due to us;

  - any further significant impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and government responses related
thereto; and

   - the need to fund maintenance capital expenditures.

If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under the
Revolving Credit Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity
needs, we may be forced to:

   - reduced or delay our business activities and capital expenditures;

   - sell assets;

   - obtain additional debt or equity financing; and/or

   - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.

We may not accomplish any of the foregoing alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if
at all. In addition, the terms of the Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility and any future debt may limit our
ability to pursue any of these alternatives.

_Cash Flows from (used in) Operating Activities_

for the three months ended March 31, 2020 to an inflow of €9.6 million for the three months ended
March 31, 2021, primarily due to (i) the €4.3 million increase in profit before taxation compared to the
three months ended March 31, 2020, (ii) the €11.1 million reduction in negative changes in trade
receivables, payables and inventory compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020 and (iii) the €0.7
million decrease in taxes compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. These positive effects were
partly offset by the €3.6 million decrease in net financial expenses and the €0.3 million increase in gains on
the sale of non-current assets and the €0.2 million decrease in other operating items.

Net cash flows from operating activities decreased €9.5 million from €86.7 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 to €77.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to the decrease
of: (i) €21.2 million of higher loss before taxation partially offset by higher net financial expenses of
€6.7 million and higher depreciation and amortization of €1.8 million; and (ii) €5.9 million in changes in
trade receivables, payables and inventory. These decreases were partly offset by the €3.2 million
improvement in cash flows for taxes, mainly due to the deferral of payment of indirect taxes such as VAT
in the United Kingdom as part of liquidity support measures introduced by the government of the United
Kingdom in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

€1.6 million for the acquisition of an additional 10% in the share capital of the Group’s UK associate
SharpEnd Partnership Ltd., compared to €12.2 million for the acquisition of Closurelogic’s business in
Germany and €0.9 million for the subscription of the first minority stake of 20% in the share capital of

Capital Expenditure decreased by €0.5 million from €9.5 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020

_Dividends_

Pursuant to Article 20.2 of the Issuer’s by-laws, the net profit resulting from the financial results will
be distributed among the Issuer’s shareholders, after deduction of the 5% to be allocated to the legal
reserve, until this reserve will have reached 1/5 of the share capital, pursuant to what is resolved by the
Board of Directors. Moreover, pursuant to Article 20.3 of the Issuer’s by-laws, the Board of Directors of
the Issuer may, during the course of a financial year, distribute interim dividends pursuant to the law in
force from time to time. In 2020, we made a distribution of dividends to non-controlling investors in the
amount of €6.9 million.

The ability of the Issuer to distribute dividends to its shareholders will be subject to any contractual
restrictions, including the restricted payments covenants in the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility.

**Contingent Liabilities and Commitments**

We are involved, from time to time, in lawsuits, claims, investigations and proceedings, arising in the
ordinary course of business. Except for potential liabilities for which we have accrued sufficient provisions,
as at the date of this Offering Memorandum, there are no such matters pending that our management
expects to be material in relation to our business, consolidated financial position, results of operations or
cash flows.

Our determination of the treatment of contingent liabilities in the financial statements is based on a
view of the expected outcome of the applicable contingency. We consult legal counsel on matters related to
litigation. We also consult with experts both within and outside our company with respect to other matters
that arise in the ordinary course of business. Examples of such matters that are based on assumptions,
judgments and estimates are the amount to be paid to settle certain other liabilities. A liability is accrued if
the likelihood of an adverse outcome is probable, or if both its occurrence and the amount it will cost are
estimable.

**Net Capital Expenditure**

Our capital expenditure and investments relate primarily to extending, upgrading and maintaining our
production facilities, research and development activities and investments in new technologies as well as
expenditures to comply with applicable environmental, health and safety (“EHS”) law and regulations and
sustainability. We define Net Capital Expenditure as Acquisitions of property, plant and equipment and
intangible assets less Proceeds from sale of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets in our
Statement of cash flows. On average, our Net Capital Expenditure represents between 5.5% and 6.5% of
our net revenue.

For purposes of this presentation, we also present Growth Capital Expenditure (which includes
investments in NFC technologies), Maintenance Capital Expenditure and EHS and Sustainability Capital
Expenditure. Growth Capital Expenditure includes discretionary investments to expand our geographical
footprint or increase our manufacturing capacity and capabilities and cost savings and efficiency projects to
optimize our operations, equipment and footprint. Growth Capital Expenditure also includes certain
discretionary investments in the design, development and production of solutions with embedded NFC
technologies. Maintenance Capital Expenditure includes critical ordinary course investments in tangible
and fixed assets to ensure the continuing operation of our asset base. EHS and Sustainability Capital
Expenditure includes expenditures related to applicable EHS laws and regulations and sustainability.
