**Critical Accounting Policies**

The accounting policies described below are those we consider critical in preparing our Financial
Statements. These policies include significant estimates and assumptions made by management using
information available at the time the estimations are made. The application of these estimates and
assumptions affects the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets
and liabilities at the balance sheet date and the reported amounts of income and expenses during the
reporting period. Actual results may differ from these estimates given the uncertainty surrounding the
assumptions and conditions upon which the estimates are based.

A more detailed description of the significant accounting policies used by us in preparing our
consolidated financial statements is included in note 2 to our 2020 Financial Statements and our
Unaudited Interim Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Accounting for business combinations_**

The Group accounts for business combinations using the acquisition method when the acquired set of
activities and assets meets the definition of a business and control is transferred to the Group. In
determining whether a particular set of activities and assets is a business, the Group assesses whether the
set of assets and activities acquired includes, at a minimum, an input and substantive process and whether
the acquired set has the ability to produce outputs.

The Group has an option to apply a “concentration test” that permits a simplified assessment of
whether an acquired set of activities and assets is not a business. The optional concentration test is met if
substantially all of the fair value of the gross assets acquired is concentrated in a single identifiable asset or
group of similar identifiable assets. The consideration transferred in the acquisition is generally measured
at fair value, as are the identifiable net assets acquired. Any goodwill that arises is tested annually for
impairment. Any gain on a bargain purchase is recognized in profit or loss immediately. Transaction costs
are expensed as incurred, except if related to the issue of debt or equity securities.

The consideration transferred does not include amounts related to the settlement of pre-existing
relationships. Such amounts are generally recognized in the profit or loss statement.

Any contingent consideration is measured at fair value as at the date of acquisition. If an obligation to
pay contingent consideration that meets the definition of a financial instrument is classified as equity, then
it is not remeasured and settlement is accounted for within equity. Otherwise, other contingent
consideration is remeasured at fair value at each reporting date and subsequent changes in the fair value of
the contingent consideration are recognized in the profit or loss statement.

If share-based payment awards (replacement awards) are required to be exchanged for awards held by
the acquirer’s employees (acquirer’s awards), then all or a portion of the amount of the acquirer’s
replacement awards is included in measuring the consideration transferred in the business combination.
This determination is based on the market-based measure of the replacement awards compared with the
market-based measure of the acquirer’s awards and the extent to which the replacement awards relate to
pre-combination service.

117


-----

**_Impairment of non-financial assets_**

As of each reporting date, the Group reviews the carrying amounts of its non-financial assets, except
for inventories and deferred tax assets, to determine whether there is any indication of impairment. If any
such indication exists, then the asset’s recoverable amount is estimated. Goodwill is tested annually for
impairment.

For impairment testing, assets are grouped together into the smallest group of assets that generates
cash inflows from continuing use that are largely independent of the cash inflows of other assets or cash
generating units (“CGUs”). Goodwill arising from a business combination is allocated to CGUs or groups
of CGUs that are expected to benefit from the synergies of the combination.

The recoverable amount of an asset or CGU is the greater of its value in use and its fair value less
costs to sell. Value in use is based on the estimated future cash flows, discounted to their present value
using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the
risks specific to the asset or CGU.

An impairment loss is recognized if the carrying amount of an asset or CGU exceeds its recoverable
amount.

Impairment losses are recognized in the profit or loss statements. They are allocated first to reduce
the carrying amount of any goodwill allocated to the CGU, and then to reduce the carrying amounts of the
other assets in the CGU on a pro rata basis.

An impairment loss in respect of goodwill is not reversed. With respect to other assets, an impairment
loss is reversed only to the extent that the asset’s carrying amount does not exceed the carrying amount
that would have been determined, net of depreciation or amortization, if no impairment loss had been
recognized.

**_Income taxes_**

Income taxes comprise current and deferred tax. They are recognized in profit or loss except to the
extent that they relate to a business combination, or items recognized directly in equity or in other
comprehensive income.

Current tax comprises the expected tax payable or receivable on the taxable profit or loss for the year
and any adjustment to tax payable or receivable in respect of previous years. It is measured using tax rates
enacted or substantially enacted at the reporting date. Current tax also includes any tax arising from
dividends as well as any tax arising from dividends and any interest and penalties imposed by the tax
authorities following their review of the tax position of previous years which found a difference in tax due.

Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets
and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes.

Deferred tax is not recognized for:

temporary differences in the initial recognition of assets or liabilities in a transaction that is not a
business combination and that affects neither accounting nor taxable profit or loss;

temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, associates and joint arrangements, to the
extent that the Group is able to control the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences and it is
probable that they will not reverse in the foreseeable future;

taxable temporary differences arising on the initial recognition of goodwill.

Deferred tax assets are recognized for unused tax losses and unused tax credits to the extent that it is
probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used. Deferred tax assets are
reviewed at each reporting date and are reduced to the extent that it is no longer probable that the related
tax benefit will be realised. Deferred tax is measured at the tax rates that are expected to be applied to
temporary differences when they reverse, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting
date. The measurement of deferred tax reflects the tax consequences that would follow from the manner in
which the Group expects, at the reporting date, to recover or settle the carrying amount of its assets and
liabilities. The income tax related to dividends are recognized when the dividend is approved.

In determining the amount of current and deferred tax, the Group takes into account the impact of
uncertain tax positions and whether additional taxes and interest may be due. The Group believes that its

118


-----

accruals for tax liabilities are adequate for all open tax years based on its assessment of many factors,
including interpretations of tax law and prior experience. This assessment relies on estimates and
assumptions and may involve a series of judgments about future events. New information may become
available that causes the Group to change its judgment regarding the adequacy of existing tax liabilities;
such changes to tax liabilities will affect tax expense in the period that such a determination is made.

**_Provision_**

Provisions include certain or probable costs and charges, the amount or due date of which is unknown at
the end of the financial year. A provision is recognized when (i) a company has a present obligation (legal
or constructive) as a result of a past event, (ii) it is probable that an outflow from the company of resources
embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation and (ii) a reliable estimate can be
made of the obligation. The provisions are stated as the best estimate of the expenditure required to settle
the obligation at the reporting date or to transfer it to a third party at that date. If the impact of
discounting the time value of money is significant, the provision is determined by discounting expected
future cash flows using a pre-tax discount rate that reflects the current market assessment of the time value
of money. Where discounting is used, the increase in the provision due to the passage of time is recognized
as interest expense.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk**

During the periods under review, we have been, and we expect that we will continue to be principally
exposed to market risk from changes in the prices of raw materials, foreign currency exchange rates and
interest rates. We monitor and manage those risks as an integral part of our overall risk management
which recognizes the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to reduce their potentially adverse
effects on our results.

**_Currency Risk_**

This risk relates to the effect of fluctuations in exchange rates on sales and purchases in currencies
other than the functional currencies of the various Group entities. The Group is exposed to currency risk,
particularly in relation to fluctuations of the U.S. dollar, British pound, Australian dollar, Indian rupee,
Ukrainian hryvnia and Polish zloty.

Interest on loans is denominated in the currency of the cash flows generated by the group’s underlying
transactions. The risk of exchange fluctuations is managed by using currency hedges from time to time
when significant differences between cost and revenue in foreign currency were noticed and such
differences were hedged through currency swaps. These provided for the purchase/sale of agreed amounts
in foreign currency at a set exchange rate against the euro.

The impact of exchange rates fluctuations on our results of operations is significant. For more
information, see “—Principal factors affecting our results of operations—Fluctuations in currency exchange
_rates” and note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

**_Credit Risk_**

This is the risk that a customer or the counterparty to a financial instrument is unable to meet an
obligation, leading to a financial loss. These risks arise mainly in relation to trade receivables and financial
investments.

The Group’s exposure to credit risk depends largely on each customer’s specific characteristics. The
demographics of the Group’s customer portfolio, including the segment insolvency risk and the country
risk, have an impact on the credit risk. See note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further
information.

The Group accrues a loss allowance equal to the estimated losses on trade and other loans and
receivables. This allowance comprises both the recognition of impairment losses for material individual
amounts and the recognition of collective impairment for similar groups of assets to cover losses already
incurred but not yet identified. The collective impairment losses are calculated on the basis of historical
payment statistics.

Most of the Group’s trade receivables are due from leading operators of the alcoholic and
non-alcoholic beverage segment. Most of its trading relationships are with long-standing customers. The
Group reduces its credit risk using supplier financing lines made available by its main customers and
factoring without recourse part of its trade receivables.

119


-----

The Group’s historical figures indicate a modest amount of credit losses. The risk is fully covered by
the corresponding loss allowance recognized in the Financial Statements.

There are no cases of particularly concentrated credit risk in geographical terms.

**_Liquidity risk_**

This risk relates to the Group’s ability to meet its obligations arising from financial liabilities. The
Group’s approach to liquidity management is to ensure adequate funds are always available to meet its
obligations at the expiry dates, both in normal conditions and at times of financial difficulty, without
incurring borrowing expense at terms higher than market conditions.

The Group generally ensures there is sufficient cash and cash equivalents to cover forecast short-term
operating expenses, including those related to financial liabilities. Contingent effects arising from extreme
situations that cannot reasonably be forecast, such as natural disasters, are excluded from the above.

The aim of the Group’s financing strategy is to maintain a well-balanced maturity profile for liabilities
to thereby reduce the refinancing risk.

Historically, the Group has always met its obligations on time and has been able to re-finance
indebtedness before its expiry.

See note 30, 31 and 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further information.

**_Interest rate risk_**

Interest rate risk relates to volatility of the market rates that determine the interest expense paid on
outstanding loans. The Group is currently exposed to interest rate risk as almost all of its financial
liabilities is subject to the payment of interest at floating rates subject to short-term repricing, including
borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and indebtedness under the Existing Notes. Any
borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility will also be subject to such interest rate risk. The Group
does not currently deem it necessary to hedge the portion of the liability subject to interest rate risk given
the current EURIBOR parameters.

As of December 31, 2020, we estimated that a hypothetical increase of 100 basis point in the interest
rate on our floating rate borrowings could have the net effect of increasing our cash outflows for the year
ended December 31, 2020 by €7.1 million.

See note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further information.

**_Raw material price risk_**

As a result of the nature of its activities, the Group is exposed to the risk of fluctuations in the
purchase price of raw materials, particularly plastics and aluminum.

The risk of fluctuations in the purchase price of plastics has not been hedged, as these raw materials
were not listed on international markets (the London Metal Exchange). However, the risk of fluctuations
in the purchase price of aluminum is partly hedged based on market needs and outlook through derivatives
that set the forward purchase price as described under “—Principal factors affecting our results of
_operations—Costs for raw materials”._

See note 38 of our 2020 Financial Statements for further information.

**_Capital Management_**

The Group’s objectives in capital management are to create value for shareholders, safeguard the
Group’s future and support its future development. Therefore, the Group seeks to maintain a sufficient
level of capitalization, while providing shareholders with satisfactory returns and ensuring access to
external sources of financing at acceptable terms, including by maintaining an adequate rating. The Group
monitors its debt to equity ratio on an ongoing basis, particularly in terms of net indebtedness and cash
flows generated by operating activities. The Board of Directors carefully monitors the balance between
greater returns through the right level of indebtedness and the advantages of a sound financial position. To
achieve these objectives, the Group strives to continuously make its operations more profitable. The Board
of Directors monitors the return on capital, being total equity attributable to owners of the Group’s parent
and the amount of dividends to be distributed to holders of ordinary shares. There were no changes in the
Group’s approach to capital management during the period under review.

**INDUSTRY OVERVIEW**

**Principal markets**

Guala is a world leader in the production and sale of aluminium and plastic closures for the beverage
industry. Guala primarily manufactures closures for global premium and local brands in the global spirits
and Roll-on for wine markets. It also manufactures closures for water and other beverages as well as for
vegetable oils and other condiments.

Packaging (bottle, label and closure) is an important consideration for spirits and Roll-on for wine
producers worldwide and is increasingly becoming a significant point of differentiation as spirits and
Roll-on for wine producers compete to attract consumers. The proliferation of spirits and Roll-on for
wines available to the consumer at the retail level has made packaging increasingly important in conveying
quality and brand image. Further, consolidation within the spirits and Roll-on for wine industry and the
formation of several major international spirits and Roll-on for wine conglomerates with substantial
advertising and marketing budgets has led to an increased emphasis on branding, especially as
international spirits and Roll-on for wine producers increasingly pursue a strategy of “premiumization”
and protection of their brands. Increasingly, local or regional producers in the emerging markets are also
focusing on their packaging content in order to build new points of differentiation between their brands
and competing brands. As such, spirits and Roll-on for wine producers, both in respect of global brands
and local brands, work closely with packaging suppliers, including closures manufacturers, in order to
design the desired image for their product and to help differentiate each product from its competitors.

Closures have today become part of the brand image for renowned global spirits and Roll-on for
wines, allowing an end consumer to identify his or her favourite brand and to build a relationship with the
brand. The look and feel of a product’s closure has a significant bearing on the consumer’s perception of
quality and consistency of the brand, which is especially important for premium brands. Further, as spirits
and Roll-on for wine producers expand into the fast-growing emerging markets, protection of product
quality and brand integrity becomes increasingly important. Given the high excise duties charged in many
emerging markets on the sale of imported alcohol, emerging markets are highly susceptible to
counterfeiting of alcoholic beverages, especially premium brands. Safety closures, which provide significant
anti-counterfeiting protection to spirits manufacturers, are therefore important packaging components for
both producers and consumers, providing producers with an ability to protect their brand image and
integrity and consumers with the confidence that they are purchasing an authentic branded item that has
not been counterfeited.

The global closure market, including Roll-on for wine and Spirits, is expected to grow at
approximately 2% annually from 2021 to 2024, mainly driven by the Spirits “Safety and Luxury” segment
with its increasing penetration as well as “Roll-on for wine screw caps” segment, almost in line with
historical trends (3-5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024). As a result of the COVID-19 epidemic, the
Closure global market decreased by 8% in 2020 (representing a four billion units drop) to reach 55 billion
units. Preliminary indications for 2021 show that the market has almost entirely recovered since then.

Guala is currently heavily focused on Roll-on for wine and spirits with sizeable presence across all key
regions. Europe remains the largest market for Guala, representing 59% of its 2019 total net revenue by
main geographical segment (i.e., based on the geographical location of the subsidiary of the Group that
records the revenue rather than the location of the customer), followed by Americas and Asia regions
which represent respectively 18% and 13% of 2019 net revenue.

**Spirits closures market**

The spirits market consists of brandy and cognac, liqueurs, rum, whisky, tequila and mezcal, white
spirits (such as vodka) and other specialty spirits. Spirits closures typically have high client stickiness owing
to their low incidence on final price/packaging cost making switching an unnecessary risk. At the same
time, client relationship key drivers are proximity, caps performance and customisation (especially on
Luxury) since closures are key to preserve organoleptic properties and to enhance branding.

There are several types of closures for Spirits, categorised in four segments: (i) Roll-on, (ii) Safety,
(iii) Luxury and (iv) Other. Guala’s core products focus on Roll-on, Safety and Luxury segments, which
represent 71%, 23% and 6% of the Spirits markets, respectively.

The Roll-on segment is mainly comprised of low price brands and more generally smaller bottle sizes.
The main product from Guala is the Roll-on ROPP closure with basic tamper proofing, aluminium. This
segment represents a true opportunity in terms of costs, as it is the lowest cost option-technology at scale.

121


-----

However, traceability is compromised with production and source information which can be easily
counterfeited.

The Safety segment consists of several offerings from more basic low-cost plastic systems to more
complex combinations of advanced anti-refill and tamper-evident. The main product from Guala is the
Anti-Refill insert (basic plastic insert) beneath with aluminium ROPP closure. This segment is mainly
driven by guaranteed quality to consumer from both tamper and anti-refill, with product source traceable
and verifiable.

The Luxury segment includes a wide range of bespoke and Luxury closures. Guala offers a wide range
of closures in this segment, from ROPP+ closures with additional basic Decoration added to one-off
customized designs for highly premium products. This segment is driven by branding and customization,
with high quality perception and unique propositions. However, the relative cost is lower as high cost per
unit is applied but on higher priced bottles.

Safety and Luxury segments have been out-performing the overall market with solid historical trend
and strong outlook towards 2024. Guala is well positioned on both segments with a clear leadership on
Safety (45-55% market share in 2019). There is sizeable growth available in East Europe due to further
shift from grey spirits to official alcohol, as well as in India where solid future growth is forecasted, driven
by ongoing premiumisation and safety focus. India is one of Guala’s most dominant markets, with 50-60%
market share in 2019 in the Safety segment, and has a high forecasted annual growth of 5.8% from 2021 to
2024. Similarly, the United States is an important market for Guala, expected to grow at 4.4% annually
from 2021 to 2024, where Guala is the market leader (holding 55-65% market share in 2019). Finally, the
United Kingdom, with an expected 6.5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024) and Mexico, with an expected
3.3% CAGR between 2021 and 2024, are both countries where Guala Closures has a strong presence, with
approximately 50% and 70% market share, respectively, in 2019.

The Spirits closures market has grown at approximately 2% CAGR between 2016 and 2019, reaching
approximately 18 billion caps in focus regions, which are India, Russia, USA, UK, Poland, Ukraine and
Mexico. In such period, “Roll-on” closures remained almost flat with market share of approximately 42%
share, unlike the “Safety” caps which reached 38% share growing faster at approximately 4% CAGR.
Therefore, Safety closures are taking market share on Roll-on markets. The fastest growing segment has
been “Luxury” with approximately 8% CAGR between 2016 and 2019, with a limited penetration
(approximately 5%). The COVID-19 epidemic has severely impacted the closure industry, resulting in an
approximately 9% decrease, with a strong rebound expected in 2021 and full recovery expected to be
achieved between 2021 and 2022, depending on country by country dynamics. The post pandemic growth
trends at approximately 2.5% annual growth between 2021 and 2024 are expected to be driven by positive
outlook mainly in India, United States, United Kingdom and Mexico, with “Safety” and “Luxury” as
top-growing segments.

Guala focuses on using product range and relationships with longstanding customers to “upsell” from

There is a strong market growth trend that is expected to continue to strengthen in the next few years
with Safety and Luxury being the most attractive spirits segments, with an expected annual growth for the
Safety segment close to 4% between 2021 and 2024 and 5% for Luxury segment in the same period. The
Roll-on segment is expected to grow at a lower rate of 1% between 2021 and 2024.

Despite having similar trends across countries, several peculiarities and/or differentiated scenarios
should be considered, especially in terms of consumer habits, COVID-19 impact and closure type growth
trends, which require a country-by-country analysis:

   - India: the overall market is expected to grow from approximately 8.3 billion units in 2021 to
approximately 9.4 billion units in 2024 at a 4.2% CAGR over the same period. Safety closures are
expected to grow from 4.5 to 5.3 billion units over the same period, with Guala holding
approximately 50 to 60% market share, being the leader in such market). Safety closures are
expected to continue gaining market share from Roll-on closures (which are expected to grow from
2.7 to 2.9 billion units between 2021 and 2024) achieving approximately 6% CAGR between 2021
and 2024. COVID-19 had a severe impact on the Indian market, mainly as a result of the
restrictions adopted by the government (e.g., the 40-day ban), and a full rebound is expected in
2022. The macro-economic downturn is mostly impacting the Roll-on closure sector (consisting of
approximately 2.8 billion units in 2019), which are typically used on cheaper “country liquor”
bottles); it is expected that after the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic dissolve, demographic and
social shift towards upper classes will continue, driving higher quality spirits consumption which
would in turn positively increase demand for Safety closures (that are mainly applied to more
expensive spirits).

  - Russia: the overall market is expected to decrease by a 0.1% CAGR between 2021 and 2024 with
approximately 4.4 billion units expected to be sold between 2021 and 2024. The Roll-on segment is
expected to be the most relevant category (with approximately 1.9 billion units in 2024), with Guala
ranking second with an estimated market share of 10 to 20%). Roll-on closures are expected to lose
market shares by 2024 to Safety (with approximately 1.5 billion units in 2024) and Luxury (with
approximately 0.6 billion units in 2024), due to a trend towards premiumization.

  - United States: The Closure market is expected to grow at approximately 2% CAGR between 2021
and 2024, with approximately 1.7 and 1.8 billion units sold in 2021 and 2024, respectively. Roll-on
closures and other closures represent the over 90% of total market); however, it is expected that
Safety closures (in which Guala holds a market share of over 50%) will gain market share.

  - United Kingdom: The Roll-on market had approximately 62% market share in 2019. The overall
closure market is expected to increase by 2.6% annually between 2021 and 2024 (from
approximately 1.5 to approximately 1.6 billion units in 2021 and 2024, respectively), supported by a
rebound in local consumption after decreasing by 11% in 2020 compared to the previous year. It is
expected that in 2022 the market will recover to the 2019 pre-COVID-19 levels.

  - Poland and Ukraine: Poland is expected to grow at 0.5% CAGR between 2021 and 2024 (with
approximately 0.9 and approximately 1.0 billion units sold in 2021 and 2024, respectively). The
Polish market is focused on Roll-on closures (with approximately 75% market share), which trend is
expected to continue. The Ukraine market is expected to decline by 0.5% CAGR between 2021 and
2024 (with approximately 0.6 billion units expected to be sold 2024), Luxury closures (representing
approximately 25% market share) are expected to further grow supported by the trend of
premiumization. Both the Polish and Ukraine markets are expected to recover to the 2019
pre-COVID-19 levels in 2022.

   - Mexico: The closure market (with approximately 0.6 billion units expected to be sold in 2024) is
strictly tied to export dynamics (mainly of tequila). The market is fairly balanced between Roll-on
and Safety closures (with Guala Closures holding approximately 60 to 70% market share in the
Safety sector), with Safety closures expected to gain approximately 1% in 2024 compared to 2021,
supported by the trend of premiumization. The overall closure market is expected to grow at 3%
CAGR between 2021 and 2024. The Closure market is expected to recover to pre-COVID-19 level
in 2021.

**Roll-on for winecap closures market**

The Roll-on for wine closures market comprises traditional corks, synthetic corks and aluminium
Roll-on for winecaps, with corks traditionally being the predominant type of Roll-on for wine closure.
However, there has recently been increased adoption of aluminium Roll-on for winecaps, due to certain
advantages, including improved preservation of the organoleptic properties of Roll-on for wine, consumer
preference for ease of use and storage, and lower cost of packaging. Corks, which deteriorate over time, do
not perform as well when travelling long distances over extended periods of time and often cause
contamination of the Roll-on for wine. Moreover, Roll-on for winecaps are not susceptible to natural cork
taint issues and therefore substantially reduce risk of spoiling. As a result, we have seen significant growth
in the metal screw cap market in recent years as Roll-on for wine producers, wholesalers and retailers
increasingly substitute metal for cork Roll-on for winecaps. We believe that metal screw caps today
account for approximately 23% of all bottled Roll-on for wine worldwide and we believe that Guala is well
positioned to capitalize on future growth in this industry.

Screw cap market volumes depend on the adoption of bottled liquids and the adoption of screw caps.

On the one hand, bottled volume drivers depend on domestic demand (with Roll-on for wine volumes
driven by population and per capita consumption); production (with volumes produced by the national
Roll-on for wineries impacting import share of consumption); volumes of imported and exported bulk and
bottled Roll-on for wines; and size of packaging (with bottle formats changes impacting the number of
closure compared to the actual volumes of Roll-on for wine being sold).

On the other hand, the screw cap penetration depends on, among others, consumer acceptance (with
consumer preference and habits being slow and difficult to change, with traditional European countries
historically preferring cork over screwcaps); production landscape (fragmented Roll-on for wineries versus
fewer concentrated large importer can favor the adoption of screw cap over corks); export share and
consumer preferences of recipient countries (high exporting countries can based their decision on the
adoption of screwcaps on the preferences of end consumers in the countries where the Roll-on for wine is
dispatched); and retailer penetration (with retailer preferring screwcaps as there is less risk of return for
tainted Roll-on for wine).

Guala is the global leader in the screwcaps attractive market (with a market share of approximately
25 to 35% and approximately 7 billion of units sold in 2019 and 2020), growing at 3% CAGR between 2016
and 2019, due to evolving consumer habits, and the ability of screwcaps to preserve production quality
while having a low incidence on the price and costs of packaging. Furthermore, the screwcap market has
also demonstrated a higher resiliency to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to the overall
closure market, showing a strong rebound in 2021, further boosted by an approximately 3% CAGR growth
expected between 2021 and 2024 and approximately 8 billion of units expected to be sold in 2024.

The overall 32 billion units Roll-on for wine closures market showed a slow but steady growth
between 2016 and 2019 of 1% CAGR, which is expected to continue over the next years, supported by
stable consumption in “Roll-on for wine countries” due to the undergoing product innovation and a
broader consumer base.

Screwcaps overall market was supported by favorable trends such as practicality, sustainability,
enhanced performance and reduced or stable cost, with the screwcap market representing approximately
23% of the overall closure market in 2019 and further growth expectation in the next years (as it is
expected to increase at a slow but steady rate of up to approximately 24% in 2024.

4% expected growth between 2021 and 2024.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We believe that we are the world’s leading producer of high value added closures for the spirits and
wine industry. Through ongoing development and technological innovation, we believe that we are the top
producer of non-refillable safety closures for the spirits industry with a market share by volume of units
sold worldwide of more than 60%, the leading global producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures
with a market share by volume of units sold of approximately 30%, and Europe’s largest producer of
roll-on aluminum closures for wine, spirits and olive oil, in each case, in 2019. In aggregate, as of March 31,
2021, we operated from 30 production facilities, five research and development centers and three sales
centers across 25 countries in five continents, and we produced and sold approximately 17 billion closures
across than 300 models and in more than 100 countries in 2020.

Our product lines include: Safety closures, Luxury closures, Roll-on closures and Roll-on for wine
closures. We serve customers in several geographies and across four key end-markets: Spirits, Wine, Water
and Beverages, and Oil and Condiments.

We believe that our global footprint and technologically advanced facilities, blue-chip customer base,
technology and innovation and effective cost control provide us with a competitive advantage over other
closures producers and make it more challenging for new market entrants to effectively compete in the
markets in which we sell our products. Our position is further consolidated by our extensive IP portfolio,
with, as of March 31, 2021, over 170 active patents and other IP rights related to the design and
manufacture of closures, and continuous product innovation (over 35 new products have been launched
over the last three years).

We are the leading producer of safety closures by volume of units sold in a number of countries,
including Colombia, India, Mexico and Ukraine. Notably, safety, closures are primarily used in emerging
markets where there is a high risk of counterfeiting of alcohol. In addition, we are the leading
manufacturer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures in Argentina, Australia, New Zealand, Poland
(from where we serve the European market) and South Africa.

We have a wide customer portfolio, which includes blue-chip major international and regional brands
with whom we have built long-term relationships lasting more than 30 years in certain cases. We supply the
top 10 premium spirits brands worldwide, including McDowell’s, Johnnie Walker, Bacardi, Jack Daniel’s
and Absolut. The breadth and diversity of our customer base results in no single brand accounting for
more than 3% of our net revenue during the last three years.

Over the past decade, we have developed a strong focus on sustainability and ESG issues and strived
to reduce the impact of our products and operations on the environment and climate change. We have
made a long-term commitment to the design of sustainable solutions and continuously focus, together with
selected partners, on the study, prototyping and development of closures made of materials with a low
environmental impact over their life cycle, including recycled aluminum and recycled polymers as well as
biopolymers and composite polymers. In 2020, recycled materials represented 27% of the raw materials
used in our products. In November 2020, we launched a new range of sustainable products under the
umbrella brand Blossom[™] and in December 2020, we signed an exclusivity agreement with Oceanworks[®],
the largest global marketplace for sustainable materials, in order to develop a line of T-bar closures

manufactured using fully recycled ocean-diverted plastic. We are committed to reducing the impact of our
operations and wider value chain on the environment by reducing waste, increasing energy and water
savings and using renewable energy, which is well-aligned with our focus on staying at the forefront of
product innovation. We estimate that in 2020 we reduced our Scope 1 & 2 Greenhouse Gas Emissions per
ton of finished products by approximately 8% compared to 2016. With plants and offices in 25 countries
and customers from over 100 countries, we also place great importance on diversity and inclusion as well as
talent recruitment and management. As of March 31, 2021, the percentage of women holding leadership
positions was 20.0% compared to 15.9% in 2018. In addition, following the appointment of the new board
of directors on April 30, 2021, 44% of the members of our board of directors are women.

For the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, we generated net revenue of €564.4 million, loss of

EBITDA margin of 17.4%. We believe that our high margins are supported by our raw material cost
management and our ability to manage raw material price fluctuations, global diversity and exposure to
growth markets and ongoing management initiatives to improve production efficiencies.

**Competitive strengths**

We believe we have the following competitive strengths:

**_Market leader in safety closures for spirits and roll-on for wine closures_**

According to a study that we commissioned from a global management company, in 2019, the global
spirits closures market reached approximately 51 billion of units sold, of which approximately 18 billion
units in our key focus regions of India, Russia, the United States, the United Kingdom, Poland, Ukraine
and Mexico, and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of approximately 2.0% between
2021 and 2024, primarily driven by growth in the safety and luxury closures markets, especially in the
United States and India. According to the same study, Guala’s global addressable Roll-on and Safety
closures markets reached approximately 37 billion units in 2019 (compared to 33 billion in 2016). In
addition, the global market for Roll-on for wine closures reached approximately 32 billion units in 2019
(compared to 30 billion units in 2016) and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of
approximately 2.0% between 2021 and 2024. We believe we are the market leader in the production of
Safety closures for spirits with a market share by volume of units sold worldwide of more than 60%, and
the leading producer of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures for the wine industry with a market share by
volume of units sold of approximately 30%, in each case in 2019. We estimate that in 2019, our market
shares for Safety and Roll-on for wine closures was six and four times greater than that of our nearest
competitor, respectively. We also believe that we are a leading producer of aluminum closures for spirits in
Europe. We believe that our leadership positions are sustainable due to our commitment to quality,
research and development efforts, proprietary production technologies, long-standing customer
relationships, excellent customer service and brand recognition.

We are a renowned as a key partner in the spirits markets and sell our safety closures to some of the
most prestigious multinational producers of spirits as well as a number of important regional producers in
many of the countries in which we operate. For a spirits producer, packaging and brand are key elements
in product identification and differentiation. Through technological innovation, we offer closures that
enable our customers to better differentiate and position their brands against their competitors. We
believe that the market for safety closures for spirits, including in emerging markets where premium
brands are penetrating further, will continue to grow. See “Industry Overview”. Our safety closures help
global manufacturers of spirits to protect against counterfeiting, particularly in emerging markets where
the risk of counterfeiting is higher. As a result, we believe that we are the leading manufacturer of safety
closures in various emerging countries, including Colombia, India, Mexico and Ukraine. Both global and
local manufacturers of spirits also use safety and luxury closures to differentiate their brands.

Our aluminum screwcaps for wine closures are designed to facilitate opening and closing the bottle
and feature liners that keep the oxygenation of the wine in check so the wine retains its quality and flavour
longer. In this market, we serve some of the major wine producers as well as a number of important
regional players, such as Casella in New Zealand, Distell in South Africa and The Wine Group in the
United States. We expect that the market for aluminum screwcaps for wine closures will continue to grow
due to the advantages of aluminum screwcaps for wine closures over traditional cork closures. We believe
that we are well placed to benefit from this growth because of our ability to cross-sell to manufacturers
who also sell spirits, our capacity for decoration and design, the economies of scale permitted by our

extensive distribution network and the proximity of several of our plants to “New World” wine producers
in Australia, New Zealand, South America and South Africa.

facilities and five research and development centers and three sales offices in 25 countries across five
continents as of March 31, 2021.
